{{EngvarB|date=March 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{multiple issues| {{COI|date=July 2013}} {{unreliable sources|date=July 2013}} {{MOS|date=June 2011}} }}
[[File:Hanan Kattan.jpeg|thumb|right]] '''Hanan Kattan''' (born May 22, 1962) is a Jordanian-born, British-based [[film producer]] of Palestinian origin. She is also co-owner of online marketing agency '''EBS Digital''', multi-media entertainment company [[Enlightenment Productions]] and a Palestinian restaurant, Tabun Kitchen.
Kattan created [[Enlightenment Productions]]<ref name=Fuchs>{{cite news|last=Fuchs|first=Ellise|title=It's the Film at Work: Interview with Shamim Sarif and Hanan Kattan|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/feature/144901-interview-with-shamim-sarif-and-hanan-kattan/|accessdate=17 March 2013|newspaper=Popmatters|date=12 August 2011}}</ref> and EBS Digital in partnership with [[Shamim Sarif]].<ref>Rachel Beebe, [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-206357148.html "Shamim Sarif and Hanan Kattan.(Q+A)"], ''[[Curve (magazine)|Curve]]'', 1 May 2009 {{subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}.</ref>
[[Enlightenment Productions]] were Winner of the Kingston Business Excellence Awards 2014, Best Creative and Media Sector Business.<ref>{{cite web|title=2014 WINNERS|url=http://www.kingstonawards.co.uk/2014-Winners|website=Kingston Business Excellence Awards 2014|accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref>
EBS Digital were Highly Commended in the Kingston Business Excellence Awards 2014 in the section for Best Business for Marketing and Social Media.<ref>{{cite web|title=2014 WINNERS|url=http://www.kingstonawards.co.uk/2014-Winners|website=Kingston Business Excellence Awards 2014}}</ref>
==Career== Kattan has produced three feature films through Enlightenment Productions including 1950s South African drama/love story ''[[The World Unseen]]'' and contemporary urban romantic comedy ''[[I Can't Think Straight]]''.<ref name=Scott>{{cite news|last=Scott|first=Rachel|title=Having a gay old time|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/apr/02/shamim-sarif|accessdate=17 March 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=2 April 2009}}</ref> She also conceived the 2010 [[TED (conference)|TEDx]] Holy Land Conference, which brought together Arab and Israeli women to discuss issues of mutual interest in technology, entertainment and design, which then became the subject of the 2011 documentary film, ''[[The House of Tomorrow (documentary)|The House of Tomorrow]]'', directed by Sarif.<ref>Billy Cox, [http://arts.heraldtribune.com/2012-04-16/section/review-house-of-tomorrow-infused-with-excitement-and-optimism/ "‘House of Tomorrow’ infused with excitement and optimism"], ''[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]'', 16 April 2012.</ref>
At [[Cannes Festival]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screendaily.com/festivals/cannes/kurylenko-furtwangler-fall-for-snow/5056295.article|title=Kurylenko, Furtwangler fall for Snow|publisher=|accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref> 2013 [[Shamim Sarif]] and Hanan announced their new film [http://www.enlightenment-productions.com/despitethefallingsnow/ Despite The Falling Snow].<ref>Despite the Falling Snow. Retrieved from https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2474932/news</ref> The film starring Mission Impossible 5 Swedish actress [[Rebecca Ferguson]],<ref>6 Sales Takes Rebecca Ferguson-Starrer ‘Snow’. Retrieved from https://variety.com/2015/film/global/six-sales-rebecca-ferguson-despite-the-falling-snow-1201479102/</ref><ref>Rebecca Ferguson. Retrieved from https://variety.com/t/rebecca-ferguson/</ref><ref>Rebecca Ferguson describes her big leap into 'Mission: Impossible'. Retrieved from http://www.mercurynews.com/movies/ci_28578922/rebecca-ferguson-describes-her-big-leap-into-mission</ref><ref>Mission: Impossible 5 Has Found Its New Female Lead. Retrieved from http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Mission-Impossible-5-Has-Found-Its-Female-Lead-43820.html</ref> [[Game of Thrones]] actor [[Charles Dance]], [[Oliver Jackson-Cohen]], [[Antje Traue]], [[Sam Reid (actor)|Sam Reid]], [[Anthony Head]] and [[Trudie Styler]], which was released in 2015.
The film has won 13 awards to date, 3 at the Prague International Film Festival<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prague-film-festival.com/winners-2016.html|title=PIFF 2016 Winners {{!}} PIFF 2017|last=PIFF|website=www.prague-film-festival.com|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> 3 more at the Milan International Film Festival<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.miffawards.com/awards/cinema.php?lang=it|title=Cinema {{!}} Miff Awards|website=www.miffawards.com|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> and others at Los Angeles,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://despitethefallingsnow.brownpapertickets.com/|title=LAWOMENSFEST: Despite the Falling Snow Opening Night Gala|website=despitethefallingsnow.brownpapertickets.com|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> Manchester,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.maniff.com/maniff2016/|title=MANIFF 2016|website=Manchester Film Festival|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> Sedona,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sedonafilmfestival.org/Page.asp?NavID=173|title=Sedona Film Festival - 2016 Festival Award-Winners|website=www.sedonafilmfestival.org|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> Buffalo,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thebnff.com/2016-bnff-award-winners/|title=2016 BNFF Award Winners – Buffalo Niagara Film Festival|website=thebnff.com|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> Soho and Orlando <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://orlandofilmfest.com/|title=Orlando Film Festival – The Orlando Film Festival|website=orlandofilmfest.com|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> Film Festivals
Kattan published her first book ''Grow Your Profits''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/13819299-grow-your-profits|title=Grow Your Profits|publisher=|accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref> about online marketing in 2012 through [[Enlightenment Productions]].
In 2013 Kattan won''Entrepreneur of the Year'' award at the Kingston Business Awards.<ref>http://pressreleaseonline.co.uk/ebs-digital-founder-hanan-kattan-wins-entrepreneur-of-the-year-200/</ref>
On 14 September 2014 [[Enlightenment Productions]] was announced as one of the finalists for Breaking the Mould Award, a prize aimed to promote and enhance the role of women in business.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/money/smallbusiness/article-2754720/Breaking-Mould-Awards-Finalists-revealed-prizes-backing-female-bosses.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490|title=Finalists revealed in prizes backing female bosses|publisher=|accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref>
In 2016 Kattan opened her Palestinian restaurant [http://www.tabunkitchen.com Tabun Kitchen]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/restaurants/tabun-kitchen|title=Tabun Kitchen|newspaper=Time Out London|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> in Soho, London.
==Filmography== *''[[I Can't Think Straight]]'' (2008) *''[[The World Unseen]]'' (2008) *''[[The House of Tomorrow (documentary)|The House of Tomorrow]]'' (2011) *''[[Despite The Falling Snow]]'' (2015)
== Personal life == After nearly 20 years she married the writer and director [[Shamim Sarif]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/shamimsarif/posts/10153608529955409|title=Shamim Sarif - We just got married! Nearly 20 years later,... {{!}} Facebook|website=www.facebook.com|access-date=2016-04-18}}</ref> They live in Surrey with their two sons, Ethan and Luca.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/HananFKattan/status/658703675456663552|title=Hanan Kattan on Twitter|website=Twitter|access-date=2016-04-18}}</ref>
==References== <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screendaily.com/5091969.article|title=Producers Lab Toronto unveils 2015 line-up|publisher=|accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref> <ref>[http://www.efp-online.com/en/news/2015/20150910_6th_PRODUCERS_LAB_TORONTO_just_kicked_off.php 6TH PRODUCERS LAB TORONTO JUST KICKED OFF]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://screenrant.com/captain-marvel-rebecca-ferguson-casting/|title=Captain Marvel: Rebecca Ferguson Rumored To Be Top Contender|date=10 September 2015|publisher=|accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/sydneylevine/producers-lab-toronto-a-success-at-tiff-2015-20150914|title=Producers Lab Toronto a Success at TIFF 2015 - IndieWire|first=Sydney|last=Levine|publisher=|accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref> {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=2331643|name=Hanan Kattan}} * [http://issuu.com/darlingmagazine/docs/darlingwimbledonfeb2015/0]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kattan, Hanan}} [[Category:Palestinian film producers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Palestinian businesspeople]] [[Category:People from London]] [[Category:LGBT people from England]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{infobox brand | name = Havana Club | logo = [[File:Havanaclublogo.png]] | image = | caption = | type = Rum | currentowner = [[Corporación Cuba Ron]] | origin = [[Santa Cruz del Norte]], [[Cuba]] | introduced = 1934 | discontinued = | related = [[Havana Club (Bacardi)]] | markets = Global, except United States | previousowners = | trademarkregistrations = | ambassadors = | tagline = "El Ron de Cuba" | website = {{URL|havana-club.com}} }}
'''Havana Club''' is a brand of [[rum]] created in Cuba in 1934, and now one of the best-selling rum brands in the world. Originally produced in [[Cárdenas, Cuba|Cardenas]], [[Cuba]] by family-owned Jose Arechabala S.A., the brand was nationalized after the [[Cuban Revolution]] of 1959. Since 1994 it has been produced in Cuba and sold globally (except the United States) by Havana Club International, a 50:50 [[joint venture]] between [[Pernod Ricard]] and the Cuban government.
[[Bacardi]] also produces a competing product with the same name in Puerto Rico, sold only in the United States. The two companies have engaged in ongoing litigation about ownership of the brand.
== History and production == [[File:Roneria Havana Club.JPG|thumb|upright=1.5|The current distillery in Santa Cruz del Norte]]The Arechabala family founded a distillery in Cardenas, Cuba in 1878.<ref name=":0" /> Later renamed Jose Arechabala S.A., the company created the Havana Club brand in 1934, and sold rum under that name in both Cuba and the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://delafe.com/cardenas//arechabe.htm|title = Arechabala Industries|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = de la Fé|first = E.J.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20040329005992/en/Bacardi-Files-Appeal-Asks-Court-Declare-Company|title = Bacardi Files Appeal and Asks Court to Declare Company Exclusive Owner of Havana Club Brand|date = 30 March 2004|accessdate = 11 January 2015|website = Business Wire|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The company was nationalized by the Castro government in 1960.<ref name="Bloomberg">{{cite web|last1=Decker|first1=Susan|title=Pernod Ricard Loses Appeals Court Ruling in Bacardi ‘Havana Club Fight|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-29/pernod-ricard-loses-appeals-court-ruling-in-bacardi-havana-club-fight.html|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=9 January 2015}}</ref> Subsequently, the Arechabala family left Cuba for [[Spain]] and the [[United States]].
The Cuban government sold rum abroad under the Havana Club name beginning in 1972, focusing primarily on the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.goodwinprocter.com/~/media/Files/Publications/Attorney%20Articles/2006/A_Heady_Mix.pdf|title = A heady mix|last = O'Connell, Jr.|first = Robert M.|date = 2006|journal = World Trademark Review|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 11 January 2015|pages = 5–10|edition = |issue = November/December 2006}}</ref> The government focused on Havana Club because (unlike the Barcardi family) the Arechabala family had not established plants outside of Cuba and so could not produce a competing brand.<ref name=":0">{{cite book | title=Bacardi and the Long Fight for Cuba: The Biography of a Cause | publisher=Penguin | author=Gjelten | year=2008|isbn = 9780670019786|first = Tom}}</ref> The company was considered a "national jewel" by the Cuban government, and in 1977 manufacturing was moved to a new plant in [[Santa Cruz del Norte]].<ref name=":0" />
Since 1994, Cuban production and non-US global marketing of Havana Club has continued under a joint partnership between [[Pernod Ricard]] and [[Corporación Cuba Ron]].<ref name="Bloomberg" />
In 1994, Bacardi began producing rum under the Havana Club name in [[Cataño, Puerto Rico|Cataño]], Puerto Rico using a recipe given to them by Arechabala family members.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> While originally sold in only a few US states (primarily Florida), production was expanded in 2006, and in 2012, after winning a critical court battle, Bacardi announced plans to sell the rum more broadly.<ref name=":1" />
==Pernod Ricard/Bacardi trademark conflict == The Havana Club trademark has been the subject of extensive trademark litigation in the US, Spain, and World Trade Organization.<ref>{{cite book|author=Joaquín Roy|title=Cuba, the United States, and the Helms-Burton Doctrine|publisher=University Press of Florida|page=55|year=2000}}</ref>
After Jose Arechabala S.A. was nationalized, the Arechabala family left Cuba and stopped producing rum. They therefore allowed the US trademark registration for "Havana Club" to lapse in 1973. Taking advantage of the lapse, the Cuban government registered the mark in the US in 1976.<ref name=":1">{{cite news | url=http://www.miamiherald.com/incoming/article1941675.html | title=Havana Club rum dispute isn’t over yet | work=Miami Herald | date=20 July 2012 | accessdate=11 January 2015 | author=Whitefield|first = Mimi}}</ref> The brand was then assigned by the Cuban government to Pernod Ricard in 1993.
In 1994, Bacardi obtained the Arechabala family's remaining rights in the brand, and began producing limited amounts of rum bearing the name. 922 cases were sold in the US in 1995 and 1996.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title = International Business and Economics: Law and Policy|last = Stephan|first = Paul B.|publisher = LexisNexis|year = 2010|isbn = 9780327174677|location = |pages = |last2 = Roin|first2 = Julie A.|edition = 5th}}</ref> This drew litigation from Pernod Ricard.<ref name="Bloomberg" /><ref name=":3">{{cite web | url=http://www.caribbeanbusinesspr.com/news03.php?nt_id=55761&ct_id=1 | title=Bacardi wins round in Havana Club fight | publisher=Caribbean Business PR | date=30 March 2011 | accessdate=8 January 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109025423/http://www.caribbeanbusinesspr.com/news03.php?nt_id=55761&ct_id=1 | archivedate=9 January 2015 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Pernod Ricard was successful in two of the first three court holdings issued in this litigation.<ref>{{Cite journal|ssrn = 2039818|title = Rumble of the Rums: The Battle Over 'Havana Club'|last = Aste|first = Dylan M.|date = 2009|journal = Journal of Contemporary Legal issues|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |volume = 19|page = 271}}</ref>
However, in 1998, after heavy lobbying from Bacardi, the US Congress passed the "Bacardi Act", which protected trademarks related to expropriated Cuban companies, and effectively ended the first phase of the litigation by eliminating Pernod Ricard's [[Standing (law)|standing]].<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/12/19/why-congress-hates-your-cuban-rum.html|title = Why Congress Hates Your Cuban Rum|date = 19 December 2014|accessdate = 8 January 2015|website = Daily Beast|publisher = |last = Mak|first = Tim}}</ref> This act (also known as Section 211) has been applied only to the Havana Club trademark.<ref name="Bloomberg" /> The act was ruled illegal by the World Trade Organization in 2001 and 2002, on grounds that it singled out one country (Cuba).<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wto.int/english/tratop_e/dispu_e/cases_e/ds176_e.htm|title = DISPUTE SETTLEMENT: DISPUTE DS176 United States — Section 211 Omnibus Appropriations Act of 1998|date = 2 January 2002|accessdate = |website = World Trade Organization|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The United States has not yet acted to address the WTO ruling,<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.cardozoaelj.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/Farhadian.pdf|title = Stealing Bacardi's Thunder|last = Farhadian|first = Sarah L.|date = 8 June 2012|journal = Cardozo Arts and Entertainment Law Journal|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |page = 320|volume = 30}}</ref> despite a 2005 deadline and requests from the European Union.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://ipkitten.blogspot.com/2008/03/john-beast-bruton-savages-yanks.html|title = John ("the Beast") Bruton savages the yanks ... diplomatically|date = 28 March 2008|accessdate = |website = IP Kat|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
Following the initial round of litigation, a second round of litigation occurred, through both the US Federal court system and the [[Trademark Trial and Appeal Board]], focused in part on the allegedly deceptive nature of the use of "Havana" in the name of a rum produced outside of Cuba.<ref name=":5" /> This round of litigation lasted from 2009 to 2012, and again resulted in a victory for Bacardi.<ref name=":1" /> After this defeat, Pernod Ricard announced plans to market the product in the US under the "Havanista" mark,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.thespiritsbusiness.com/2014/12/pernod-moves-step-closer-to-havanista-us-launch/|title = Pernod moves step closer to Havanista US launch|date = 18 December 2014|accessdate = 11 January 2015|website = The Spirits Business|publisher = |last = Hopkins|first = Amy}}</ref> while Bacardi announced plans to extend distribution of Bacardi's version of Havana Club throughout the US.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/13/bacardi-havana-club-rum_n_1592027.html|title = Bacardi To Start Selling Havana Club Rum Across The United States|date = 13 June 2012|accessdate = |website = Huffington Post|publisher = |last = Harrison|first = Carlos}}</ref>
In Spain, Pernod Ricard's ownership of the mark has been upheld in three court rulings, most recently in 2011.<ref name=":3" />
In January 2016, after a thaw in US-Cuba relations, the U.S. government awarded a trademark for Havana Club to the Cuban government, which was "expected to reignite longstanding tension between Bacardi Ltd. and the Cuban government".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/cuba/article54863035.html|title=Cuba prevails in Havana Club rum dispute with Bacardi|last=Whitefield|first=Mimi|date=15 January 2016|work=|access-date=2016-12-06|via=|newspaper=Miami Herald}}</ref><ref name="trippmickle">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/cuban-government-granted-a-u-s-trademark-for-havana-club-rum-1452890441|title=U.S. Grants Cuban Government a Trademark for Havana Club Rum|author=Tripp Mickle|date=15 January 2016|work=WSJ|subscription=yes}}</ref> Bacardi appealed the decision, and in 2017, Florida lawmakers asked President Donald Trump to reverse the decision.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/business/international-business/article57948323.html|title=Bacardi says it’s not over yet in Havana Club trademark battle|last=Whitefield|first=Mimi|date=2 February 2016|work=|newspaper=Miami Herald|access-date=2016-12-06|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/cuba/article141553089.html|title=Florida lawmakers ask Trump administration to revoke Havana Club trademark license|last=Gámez Torres|first=Nora|date=2017-03-29|work=Miami Herald|access-date=2017-07-08|language=en}}</ref>
== Current sales and marketing == [[File:Giradilla.jpg|thumb|upright|The Giraldilla of Havana, used on the Havana Club logo and labeling.]] Pernod Ricard's Havana Club is the fifth-largest rum brand in the world, with almost 4 million cases sold in 2012–2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cubacontemporanea.com/en/havana-club-sales-3-percent|title = Havana Club Sales Up 3 Percent|date = 30 August 2013|accessdate = |website = Cuba Contemporanea|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150109041412/http://www.cubacontemporanea.com/en/havana-club-sales-3-percent|archivedate = 9 January 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref> It is sold in over 120 countries.<ref name=":1" /> Its strongest markets include France, and Germany, where marketing plays off the brand's distribution in East Germany during the Cold War.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Sun, Sex, and Socialism: Cuba in the German Imaginary|last = Hosek|first = Jennifer Ruth|publisher = University of Toronto Press|year = 2012|isbn = 9781442641389|location = |pages = 27–36}}</ref> Since 2008, it is also bottled in India, the world's second-largest rum market.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2008-08-19/news/27720124_1_bacardi-white-rum-cuban-government|title = Pernod takes on Bacardi with Havana Club|last = Kurian|first = Boby|date = 19 August 2008|work = The Economic Times|access-date = |last2 = Gupta|first2 = Swagata}}</ref>
Pernod Ricard plays heavily on Cuban themes in its marketing, including labeling Havana Club as "El Ron de Cuba" ("The Rum of Cuba").<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":4" /> It is one of the most common items brought into the US by tourists returning from Cuba.<ref name=":4" /> To avoid charges of customer deception, Bacardi's Havana Club labeling prominently mentions that it is made in Puerto Rico and is often referred to as "Havana Club Puerto Rican rum".<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url = http://tushnet.blogspot.com/2010/04/havana-club-rum-from-puerto-rico-not.html|title = Havana Club rum from Puerto Rico not false advertising|date = 15 April 2010|accessdate = 15 January 2015|website = [[Rebecca Tushnet]]'s 43(B)log: False advertising and more|publisher = |last = Tushnet|first = Rebecca}}</ref>
Pernod Ricard's labeling, originated by Cubaexport in the 1970s, is gold and red, and features the [[Castillo de la Real Fuerza#La Giraldilla|Giraldilla]], a weathervane from the old fort of Havana.<ref name=":0" /> Pernod Ricard has announced plans to use similar gold and red labels on their "Havanista" product in the United States.<ref name=":1" />
In 2016, Bacardi announced new branding and plans to sell their version of Havana Club nationally. This will be distilled in Puerto Rico and bottled in Florida.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/cuba/article81034457.html|title=Bacardi evokes Cuba’s ‘golden age’ in taking Havana Club rum national|last=Whitefield|first=Mimi|date=2016-05-31|work=Miami Herald|access-date=2017-07-08|language=en}}</ref>
==Grades and blends== [[File:Havana Club 7 anos.jpeg|thumb|upright|Havana Club 7 años]]
=== Pernod Ricard === * '''''Añejo Blanco:''''' White rum; aged 1 year. Marketed as a mixer.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Havana Club|url = http://pernod-ricard.com/532/brands/see-all-brands/strategic-brands/havana-club|accessdate = 25 May 2015|publisher = [[Pernod Ricard]]}}</ref> * '''''Añejo 3 Años:''''' Aged 3 years.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Havana Club añejo 3 años {{!}} 3 year old aged rum|url = http://havana-club.com/en/cuban-rum/anejo-3-anos-0|accessdate = 25 May 2015|publisher = [[Pernod Ricard]]}}</ref> * '''''Añejo Especial'''''<ref>{{Cite web|title = Añejo Especial Rum {{!}} Gold rum{{!}} Havana Club|url = http://havana-club.com/en/cuban-rum/anejo-especial-0|accessdate = 25 May 2015|publisher = Pernod Ricard}}</ref> * '''''Añejo Reserva'''''<ref>{{Cite web|title = Añejo Reserva Rum {{!}} Havana Club|url = http://havana-club.com/en/cuban-rum/anejo-reserva|accessdate = 25 May 2015|publisher = Pernod Ricard}}</ref> * '''''Añejo 7 Años:''''' Dark rum; aged 7 years.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Dark rum {{!}} 7 year old aged rum {{!}} Havana Club|url = http://havana-club.com/en/cuban-rum/anejo-7-anos|accessdate = 25 May 2015|publisher = Pernod Ricard}}</ref> * '''''Añejo 15 Años:''''' Limited release rum aged at least 15 years.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Añejo 15 Años Rum {{!}} Havana Club|url = http://havana-club.com/en/cuban-rum/anejo-15-anos-0|accessdate = 25 May 2015|publisher = Pernod Ricard}}</ref> Has won International Spirits Challenge awards.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ISC trophies announced|url = http://www.drinksint.com/news/fullstory.php/aid/2463/ISC_trophies_announced.html|accessdate = 25 May 2015|publisher = Drinks International}}</ref> * '''''Máximo Extra Añejo:''''' A luxury aged rum retailing for over $1,000 a bottle, with only 1,000 bottles released.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Premium Cuban Rum – Havana Club's Maximo Extra Añejo|url = http://www.luxury-insider.com/luxury-news/2008/07/premium-cuban-rum-e28093-havana-club-maximo-extra-anejo|accessdate = 25 May 2015|publisher = Luxury Insider|date = 19 July 2008}}</ref> Packaged in a hand-blown glass bottle.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Máximo Extra Añejo Rum {{!}} Havana Club|url = http://havana-club.com/en/cuban-rum/maximo-extra-anejo-0|accessdate = 25 May 2015|publisher = Pernod Ricard}}</ref> * '''''Selección de Maestros:''''' A relaunch of the 45% ABV (90 proof) "Cuban Barrel Proof" grade,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://therumhowlerblog.wordpress.com/rum-reviews/dark-rums/havana-club-seleccion-de-maestros/ | title=Havana Club Selección de Maestros | publisher=The Rum Howler Blog | date=20 May 2012 | accessdate=15 January 2015 | author=Dykstra, Chip}}</ref> Selección de Maestros ("Selections of masters") has performed well at [[spirit ratings]] competitions. For instance, at the 2014 San Francisco World Spirits Competition, it won a double gold medal. Ratings aggregator Proof66 has also placed the Selecciones de Maestros in the 99th percentile of all rums.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.proof66.com/rum/havana-club-seleccion-de-maestros.html | title=Havana Club Seleccion de Maestros | publisher=Proof66.com | accessdate=15 January 2015}}</ref> * '''''Unión''''', blended to pair with cigars.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.havanainsider.com/tasting-of-havana-club-union-rum-with-cubas-legendary-master-blender/|title=Tasting Of Havana Club Union Rum With Master Blender|date=2016-02-05|work=Havana Insider|access-date=2017-11-18|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Bacardi === * '''''Clásico''''', marketed as a sipping rum. * '''''Blanco''''', marketed as a mixer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/will-the-real-havana-club-rum-please-stand-up-2016-10-14|title=Bacardi is touting a ‘Cuban’ rum that’s actually made in Puerto Rico|last=Passy|first=Charles|work=MarketWatch|access-date=2017-11-18|language=en-US}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Cuba}} * [[Budweiser trademark dispute]] – trademark controversy between American and state-owned brewers over a beer brand
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Pernod Ricard}} {{coord|23|09|08|N|81|55|03|W|region:CU_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}}

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Intelpedia}} {{external links|date=September 2016}} [[File:Intellipedia Logo.jpg|thumb|Intellipedia Logo]] [[File:Screenshot-Intellipedia.png|thumb|A screenshot of the Intellipedia interface]] [[File:Three_wikis_that_make_up_Intellipedia2.jpg|thumb|The three wikis that make up Intellipedia.]] '''Intellipedia''' is an online system for collaborative data sharing used by the [[United States intelligence community|United States Intelligence Community]] (IC).http://www.intelink.gov {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225104427/http://www.intelink.gov/ |date=2012-02-25 }} It was established as a pilot project in late 2005 and formally announced in April 2006.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/news-information/featured-story-archive/2008-featured-story-archive/intellipedia-marks-second-anniversary.html |title=Intellipedia marks second anniversary |publisher=CIA Press Release |date=March 20, 2008}}INSA, Analytic Transformation, September 2007, p. 12. Intellipedia consists of three [[wiki]]s running on the separate [[Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communications System|JWICS]] (Intellipedia-TS), [[SIPRNet]] (Intellipedia-S), and [[DNI-U]] (Intellipedia-U) [[Computer network|networks]]. The [[Classified information|levels of classification]] allowed for information on the three wikis are [[Top Secret]] [[Sensitive Compartmented Information]] (TS SCI), [[Classified information in the United States#Secret|Secret]] (S), and [[Sensitive But Unclassified]] (SBU or [[For Official Use Only|FOUO]]) information, respectively. Each of the wikis is used by individuals with appropriate [[Security clearance|clearances]] from the 16 agencies of the [[US intelligence community]] and other national-security related organizations, including [[Unified Combatant Command|Combatant Commands]] and other federal departments. The wikis are not open to the public.Vogel, Steve, "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/08/26/AR2009082603606.html For Intelligence Officers, A Wiki Way to Connect Dots]", ''[[Washington Post]]'', August 27, 2009, p. 23. Intellipedia is a project of the [[Office of the Director of National Intelligence]] (ODNI) [[Intelink|Intelligence Community Enterprise Services]] (ICES) office headquartered in [[Fort George G. Meade|Fort Meade]], [[Maryland]]. It includes information on the regions, people, and issues of interest to the communities using its host networks. Intellipedia uses [[MediaWiki]], the same software used by the [[Wikipedia]] free-content encyclopedia project.{{cite web |url=http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2006/November/Pages/SecurityBeat2819.aspx?PF=1 |title=Wikipedia for Intel Officers Proves Useful |work=National Defense Magazine |date=November 2006 |accessdate=2006-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IvkVRnyJ?url=http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2006/November/Pages/SecurityBeat2819.aspx?PF=1 |archivedate=2013-08-17 |df= }} To the contrary of mainstream ''Wikipedia'', its intelligence analogue encourages editing that incorporates personal points of view regardless of rank as it was decided that, "much of the self-corrective knowledge in the Intelligence Community resides in personal points of view," and that, "not all good ideas originate at the top." The Secret version connected to SIPRNet predominantly serves [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] and the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]] personnel, many of whom do not use the Top Secret JWICS network on a day-to-day basis. Users on unclassified networks can access Intellipedia from remote terminals outside their workspaces via a [[VPN]], in addition to their normal workstations. [[Open Source Intelligence]] (OSINT) users share information on the unclassified Intelink-U wiki. ==History== Intellipedia was created to share information on some of the most difficult subjects facing U.S. intelligence and to bring cutting-edge technology into its ever-more-youthful workforce.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/techinnovations/2006-11-02-intellipedia_x.htm |title=Over 3,600 intelligence professionals tapping into Intellipedia |work=[[USA Today]] |agency=Associated Press |first=Katherine |last=Shrader |date=2006-02-11 |accessdate=2008-10-27}} It also allows information to be assembled and reviewed by a wide variety of sources and agencies, to address concerns that pre-war intelligence did not include robust dissenting opinions on Iraq's alleged weapons programs.[http://www.smartbrief.com/alchemy/servlet/encodeServlet?issueid=53427FBF-AE22-4442-B244-C4E7C872397A&lmid=archives "Data from spies now assembled wiki-style"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', November 1, 2006 A number of projects are under way to explore the use of the Intellipedia for the creation of traditional Intelligence Community products. In the summer of 2006, Intellipedia was the main collaboration tool in constructing a [[National Intelligence Estimate]] on [[Nigeria]].Bruce Finley, [http://www.denverpost.com/search/ci_4216851 "Intelligence Fixes Floated at Conference," ''Denver Post'', 08/22/2006] Intellipedia was at least partially inspired by a paper written for the [[Galileo Award]] (an essay competition set up by the CIA, later taken over by the DNI), which encouraged any employee at any intelligence agency to submit new ideas to improve information sharing. The first essay selected was by [[Calvin Andrus]], chief technology officer of the Center for Mission Innovation at the CIA, entitled "The Wiki and the Blog: Toward a Complex Adaptive Intelligence Community". Andrus' essay argued that the real power of the Internet had come from the boom in self-publishing, and noted how the open-door policy of [[Wikipedia]] allowed it to cover new subjects quickly.D. Calvin Andrus, Ph.D. Office of Application Services, Central Intelligence Agency. [http://www.acadac.net/wiki/images/a/af/SSRN-id755904.pdf The wiki and the blog: Toward a complex adaptive intelligence community], ''Studies in Intelligence'', Volume 49, Number 3, September 2005. Published on the Web as, {{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/csi-studies/studies/vol49no3/html_files/Wik_and_%20Blog_7.htm |title=The wiki and the blog: Toward a complex adaptive intelligence community|author=D. Calvin Andrus |publisher=Central Intelligence Agency Center for the Study of Intelligence |accessdate=2008-05-02}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/03/magazine/03intelligence.html |title=Open-Source Spying |author=Clive Thompson |work=The New York Times Magazine|date=2006-12-03|accessdate=2007-11-17}} Richard A. Russell, Deputy Assistant [[Director of National Intelligence]] for [[Information Sharing Customer Outreach (ISCO)]] said it was created so "analysts in different agencies that work X or Y can go in and see what other people are doing on subject X or Y and actually add in their two cents worth ... or documents that they have. ... What we're after here is 'decision superiority', not 'information superiority'. ... We have to get inside the decision cycle of the enemy. We have to be able to discover what they're doing and respond to it effectively." In September 2007, sixteen months after its creation, officials noted that the top-secret version of Intellipedia alone (hosted on [[Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communications System|JWICS]]) has 29,255 articles, with an average of 114 new articles and more than 6,000 edits to articles added each workday.{{cite news|first=Scott|last=Shane|title=Logged In and Sharing Gossip, Er, Intelligence|date=September 2, 2007|work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/02/weekinreview/02shane.html}} As of April 2009, the overall Intellipedia project hosted 900,000 pages edited by 100,000 users, with 5,000 page edits per day.{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1890084,00.html |title=Wikipedia for Spies: The CIA Discovers Web 2.0 |work=Time |date=2009-04-08 |accessdate=2009-04-09 |first=Massimo |last=Calabresi}} As of January 2014, Intellipedia contained around 269,000 articlesKaven Waddel. [https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2017/03/the-governments-secret-wiki-for-intelligence/518508/?google_editors_picks=true The Government’s Secret Wiki for Intelligence: Analysts reportedly tucked classified information about Russian hacking inside Intellipedia for safekeeping,] ''The Atlantic,'' March 3, 2017. with the Top Secret Intellipedia counting 113,000 content pages with 255,000 users.{{cite web|last=jasonsmathers|url=https://www.muckrock.com/foi/united-states-of-america-10/intellipedia-usage-statistics-10058/|title=FOIA request for Intellipedia usage statistics|publisher=MuckRock|accessdate=10 April 2014}} ===10 years later=== A 2017 two-part ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' series on Intellipedia and next steps reported that after 10 years of usage Intellipedia helped the IC get caught up to "Web 2.0" but never reformed how official reports were created like [[National Intelligence Estimate]]s. A more official version of Intellipedia called the Living Intelligence System was created after the fact and focused on collaboratively writing official reports. It failed to catch on because each agency has a different process for writing official, classified reports.[https://www.wired.com/2017/03/intellipedia-wikipedia-spies-much/ The Wikipedia for Spies and Where It Goes From Here], Wired, March 2017 Based on the lessons learned from Intellipedia and the Living Intelligence System, a pilot program within the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency created the Tearline apps focused on writing official collaborative reports in the less bureaucratic space of unclassified content.[https://www.wired.com/2017/04/american-spies-now-smartphone-app/ American Spies Now Have Their Own Smartphone App], Wired, April 2017 ==Potential problems== Some are concerned that individual intelligence agencies will create their own wikis, draining ideas and input from Intellipedia.{{cite web|url=http://www.marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2006/11/intellipedia.html#comment-25336444|title=Intellipedia - Marginal REVOLUTION|date=2 November 2006|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016}} Sean Dennehy, a [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] official involved in integrating the system into the intelligence fabric, said disseminating material to the widest possible audience of analysts is key to avoiding mistakes. He said analysts from multiple agencies had used the network to post frequent updates on recent events, including [[2006 New York City plane crash|the crash of a small plane into a New York City apartment building in October 2006]] and [[2006 North Korean missile test|North Korea's test of a missile in July 2006]].{{cite web|url=http://esenai.com/blog/intellipedia/people/michael_wertheimer/|title=Intellipedia Roundtable Discussion|website=esenai.com}} Some view it as risky because it allows more information to be viewed and shared;{{cite web|url=http://esenai.com/blog/intellipedia/|title=U.S. intelligence unveils spy version of Wikipedia|website=esenai.com}} but according to [[Michael Wertheimer]], [[John Michael McConnell|McConnell's]] assistant deputy director for analysis, it is worth the risk. The project was greeted initially with "a lot of resistance," said Wertheimer, because it runs counter to past practice which sought to limit the pooling of information.{{cite web|url=http://www.metimes.com/storyview.php?StoryID=20061103-075107-4557r|title=US spies create their own 'Wiki' intelligence|website=metimes.com}} He said there are risks in everything everyone does: "the key is risk management, not risk avoidance." Some encouragement has been necessary to spur contributions from the traditional intelligence community. However, he said the system appeals to the new generation of intelligence analysts because "this is how they like to work" and "it's a new way of thinking." ==Successes== [[File:Intellipedia2008.png|thumb|[[2008 Mumbai attacks]] page on Intellipedia]] [[Thomas Fingar]], [[Director of National Intelligence|Deputy Director of National Intelligence for Analysis]] (DDNI/A), cited the successful use of Intellipedia to develop an article on how Iraqi insurgents were using [[chlorine]] in [[improvised explosive devices]] saying, "They developed it in a couple of days interacting in Intellipedia,"..."No bureaucracy, no mother-may-I, no convening meetings. They did it and it came out pretty good. That's going to continue to grow."[http://defensenews.com/story.php?F=2733832&C=america "U.S. Intel Agencies Modernize Info Sharing", ''DefenseNews.com'', May 7, 2007][http://www.dni.gov/speeches/20070905_speech.pdf 2007 Analytic Transformation Symposium], 6 September 2007, p. 13 In a September 10, 2007 testimony before the [[United States Congress]], [[John Michael McConnell|Michael McConnell]], [[Director of National Intelligence]], cited the increasing use of Intellipedia among analysts and its ability to help experts pool their knowledge, form virtual teams, and make quick assessments.[http://dni.gov/testimonies/20070910_testimony.pdf Michael McConnell. "Confronting the Terrorist Threat to the Homeland: Six Years after 9/11]", ''Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee'', September 10, 2007 ''[[Analyzing Intelligence: Origins, Obstacles, and Innovations]]'', a 2008 book by several experts in the field of intelligence analysis, cited Intellipedia as evidence of the changing nature of analysis.Roger George, James Bruce, et al., ''Analyzing Intelligence: Origins, Obstacles, and Innovations'', Georgtown University Press, April 2008 [[Eric Haseltine]], former ODNI Associate Director for Science and Technology said that "It's hard to overstate what [Burke and Dennehy] did . ... They made a major transformation almost overnight with no money after other programs failed to achieve these results with millions of dollars in funding." Haseltine said intelligence analysts had "reacted 'more quickly and more intelligently' to potential terrorist threats than they would have without Intellipedia". ==Community practices== [[File:Intellipedia shovel.jpg|thumb|An Intellipedia shovel, awarded to exemplary wiki contributors.]] The wiki provides so much flexibility that several offices throughout the community are using it to maintain and transfer knowledge on daily operations and events.Executive Biz, [http://www.executivebiz.com/newsletter-executives-detail.php?who=jwilson Executive Spotlight with Jesse Wilson], October 11, 2007 Anyone with access to read it has permission to create and edit articles after registering and acquiring an account with [[Intelink]]. Since Intellipedia is intended to be a platform for harmonizing the various points of view of the agencies and analysts of the Intelligence Community, Intellipedia does not enforce a [[neutrality (philosophy)|neutral point of view]] policy.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/03/magazine/03intelligence.html?ex=1322802000&en=46027e63d79046ce&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss|title=Open-Source Spying|work=New York Times Magazine|date=December 2006|accessdate=2006-12-03 |first=Clive |last=Thompson}} Instead, viewpoints are attributed to the agencies, offices, and individuals participating, with the hope that a consensus view will emerge. Intellipedia also contains a great deal of non-encyclopedic content including meeting notes and items of internal, administrative interest. Deputy DNI [[Thomas Fingar]] made a comparison to [[eBay]], the auction Web site where the reliability of sellers is rated by buyers. He said:
Intellipedia. It's been written up. It's the Wikipedia on a classified network, with one very important difference: it's not anonymous. We want people to establish a reputation. If you're really good, we want people to know you're good. If you're making contributions, we want that known. If you're an idiot, we want that known too.{{cite web|url=http://www.cfr.org/publication/15754/intelligence_reform_rush_transcript_federal_news_service.html|title=Intelligence Reform [Rush Transcript; Federal News Service]|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016}}{{cite news |first=Mazzetti |last=Mark |title=Intelligence Chief Announces Renewed Plan for Overhaul |date=April 12, 2007 |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/12/washington/12intel.html}}
During 2006–2007, Intellipedia editors awarded symbolic ''shovels'' to users to distinguish exemplary Wiki ''gardening'' and to encourage others in the community to contribute. A template with a picture of the limited-edition shovel (actually a trowel), was created to place on user pages for Intellipedians to show their ''gardening'' status. The handle bears the imprint: "I dig Intellipedia! It's wiki wiki, Baby." The idea was inspired by the [[Wikipedia:Barnstars|barnstar]],{{cite web |url=http://www.eekim.com/blog/2006/09/27/intellipediashovel |title=EEK Speaks |work=Eugene Eric Kim's Blog |accessdate=2006-11-01}} which is used on both [[Wikipedia:Barnstars|Wikipedia]] and [[MeatballWiki]] for similar purposes. The shovels have since been replaced with a mug bearing the tag line, "Intellipedia: it's what we know". Different agencies have experimented with other ways of encouraging participation. For example, at the CIA, managers have held contests for best pages with prizes such as free dinners.{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?command=viewArticleBasic&articleId=9096658&pageNumber=1 |title=CIA, Pfizer, Wachovia and Sony execs suggest options for adopting Web 2.0 |author=Heather Havenstein |publisher=Computerworld}} Chris Rasmussen, knowledge management officer at the Defense Department's [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] (NGA), argues that "gimmicks" like the Intellipedia shovel, posters, and handbills, encourage people to use [[Web 2.0]] tools like Intellipedia and are effective low-tech solutions to promote their use. Also, Rasmussen argues that "[[social software]]–based contributions should be written in an employee's performance plan"."[http://www.fcw.com/print/13_16/news/102750-1.html Government taps the power of us: Officials turn to blogs and wikis to share information and achieve goals]", ''Federal Computer Week'', May 21, 2007 ===Training=== Several agencies in the Intelligence community, most notably the CIA and NGA,{{cite web|url=http://blog.executivebiz.com/web20-adoption-in-large-enterprises/|title=Web2.0 Adoption in Large Enterprises|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016}} have developed training programs to provide time to integrate social software tools into analysts' daily work habits. These classes generally focus on the use of Intellipedia to capture and manage knowledge, but they also incorporate the use of the other social software tools. These include [[blog]]s, [[RSS]], and social bookmarking. The courses stress immersion in the tools and instructors encourage participants to work on a specific project in Intellipedia. The courses also expose participants to social media technologies on the Internet.[http://www.federalnewsradio.com/?sid=1286296&nid=250 Radio interview] that highlights Intelligence Community social software training programs, Federal News Radio, November 5, 2007[http://www.executivebiz.com/newsletter-executives-detail.php?who=sdennehy Executive Spotlight Interview with Sean Dennehy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206042130/http://www.executivebiz.com/newsletter-executives-detail.php?who=sdennehy |date=2008-12-06 }}, ExecutiveBiz, December 5, 2007[http://www.executivebiz.com/newsletter-executives-detail.php?who=crasmussen Executive Spotlight Interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204094209/http://www.executivebiz.com/newsletter-executives-detail.php?who=crasmussen |date=2008-12-04 }} with Chris Rasmussen, ExecutiveBiz, October 25, 2007 ==Awards== In 2009, Don Burke and Sean P. Dennehy, two of the originators of Intellipedia, were awarded with the "Homeland Security Service to America Medal" by the [[Partnership for Public Service]]. The award noted that they "Promoted information sharing across the intelligence community through the development and implementation of Intellipedia, a Wikipedia-like clearinghouse of intelligence expertise."{{cite web|url=http://servicetoamericamedals.org/honorees/view_profile.php?profile=215|title=2009 'Service to America Medal Recipients' |accessdate=2010-01-05 |publisher=[[Service to America Medals]] |date=2009-09-23}} ==See also== * [[A-Space]] * [[Bureaupedia]]—the FBI's online encyclopedia * [[Classified website]] * [[Diplopedia]] * [[DoDTechipedia]] * [[Intellipublia]] ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} ==Further reading== * Frank Ahrens. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/03/AR2006110302015.html "A Wikipedia of secrets"], ''The Washington Post'', November 5, 2006. * D. Calvin Andrus, Ph.D. Office of Application Services, Central Intelligence Agency. [https://ssrn.com/abstract=755904 The wiki and the blog: Toward a complex adaptive intelligence community], ''Studies in Intelligence'', Volume 49, Number 3, September 2005. * Cody Burke. [http://epublications.bond.edu.au/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1010&context=cewces_papers Freeing knowledge, telling secrets: Open source intelligence and development], ''CEWCES Research Papers,'' Bond University, May 2007. * Matthew S. Burton. [https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/csi-studies/studies/vol49no3/html_files/Intelligence_Networking_6.htm Connecting the Virtual Dots: How the Web Can Relieve Our Information Glut and Get Us Talking to Each Other], ''Studies in Intelligence'', Vol 49, Number 3, September 2005. * Gianluigi Cesta. [http://gnosis.aisi.gov.it/Gnosis/Rivista10.nsf/ServNavigE/7 The Intellipedia experiment or rather, shared secrets], ''Gnosis (Italian Intelligence magazine of [[Agenzia Informazioni e Sicurezza Interna|AISI]]),'' No. 1, 2007. * Wilson P. Dizard III. [https://gcn.com/articles/2006/09/22/spy-agencies-adapt-social-software-federated-search-tools.aspx Spy agencies adapt social software, federated search tools], ''Government Computer News'', September 25, 2006. * [http://uk.reuters.com/article/tech-internet-intelligence-dc-idUKN0123738920061031 "U.S. intelligence unveils spy version of Wikipedia"], ''Reuters'', October 31, 2006. * Scott Shane. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/02/weekinreview/02shane.html Logged In and Sharing Gossip, er, Intelligence], ''The New York Times,'' September 2, 2007. ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [https://www.intelink.gov/wiki Official Intellipedia website] (may require an [https://www.intelink.gov/passport/servlet/PassportLogin Intelink Passport account]) * [http://www.theblackvault.com/documentarchive/intellipedia-entries/# Declassified Intellipedia Entries] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20170305032038/http://www.theblackvault.com/documentarchive/intellipedia-entries/# Archive]) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130729204530/http://itc.conversationsnetwork.org/shows/detail1891.html Jon Udell's Interviews with Innovators], Audio interview with Lewis Shepherd of the Defense Intelligence Agency about Intellipedia and Web 2.0 use within the US Intelligence Community. August 2, 2007. * Chris Rasmussen. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nbgQ1V2BLEs Toward Living Intelligence], YouTube presentation discussing the role of Intellipedia for Intelligence Community, June 2, 2009. {{United States intelligence agencies}} [[Category:2006 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Enterprise wikis]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2006]] [[Category:MediaWiki sites of the United States government]] [[Category:Open-source intelligence]] [[Category:United States intelligence agencies]] [[Category:Academic works about intelligence analysis]]

{{Infobox Award |name=James H. Doolittle Award |image=James H. Doolittle Award Trophy.png |imagesize=150px |caption=The Doolittle Trophy |description=Outstanding technical management or engineering |presenter=The Society of Experimental Test Pilots and Boeing |location=Lancaster, California |country={{USA}} |year={{Start date|1966}} |website= [http://www.setp.org/criteria/james-h-doolittle-award.html SETP] }} The '''James H. Doolittle Award''' is an honor presented annually by the [[Society of Experimental Test Pilots]]. It is an award for "outstanding accomplishment in technical management or engineering achievement in aerospace technology". The award consists of a perpetual trophy on permanent display at SETP headquarters, and a smaller replica presented to the recipient. It is named after [[Jimmy Doolittle|General James Doolittle]], famous for the [[Doolittle Raid]] on Tokyo during World War II.<ref name=Criteria>{{cite web|url=http://www.setp.org/criteria/james-h-doolittle-award.html |title=James H. Doolittle Award Criteria |publisher=Setp.org |date= |accessdate=2010-09-29}}</ref>
The Doolittle Trophy is a [[bronze]] form melding an aerodynamic shape, a stylized spacecraft, and a winged human figure. The aerodynamic shape stands for the scientists and engineers who provide technological breakthroughs. The spacecraft represents continued growth of the aerospace industry. The human figure represents the pilot who guides the test effort to reach its goals. A [[helmet]] and [[goggles]] rest on the base of the trophy symbolizing the tools of the early test pilot and Jimmy Doolittle himself. Plaques bearing the name of each honoree are mounted around the sides of the [[teak]] base.<ref name=SETP_56th>{{cite book |last= |first= |title=SETP 56th Awards Banquet Program |publisher=Society of Experimental Test Pilots |location=Lancaster, California |date=September 29, 2012}}</ref>
== Criteria == The Society lists three criteria for nominations to this award:<ref name=Criteria/> #The recipient must be a living member of the Society #A significant phase of the accomplishment must have occurred while a member of the Society #The accomplishment must clearly be in the technical management or engineering aspects of aerospace technology
==Recipients== Recipients of the SETP J. H. Doolittle Award include:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.setp.org/winners/j-h-doolittle-recipients.html |title=J. H. Doolittle Recipients | Winners |publisher=Setp.org |date= |accessdate=2015-10-10}}</ref> *1966 - [[James L. Pearce ]] *1967 - [[Richard W. Taylor]] *1968 - [[William Paul Thayer]] *1969 - [[Guy M. Townsend]], BGen., USAF (Ret) *1970 - [[William M. Magruder]] *1971 - [[C. H. Meyer]] *1972 - [[Deke Slayton|Donald K. Slayton]], NASA/MSC *1973 - [[William S. Ross]], McDonnell Aircraft Company *1974 - [[William R. Murray]] *1975 - [[Robert A. Rushworth]], Major General, USAF *1976 - [[Frank Borman]] *1977 - [[Robert C. Little]] *1978 - [[William R. Laidlaw]] *1979 - [[Thomas Patten Stafford|Thomas P. Stafford]], LGen., USAF *1980 - [[J. Lynn Helms]] *1981 - [[Thomas B. Hayward]], Admiral, USN *1982 - [[Allen E. Paulson]] *1983 - [[Herbert Z. Hopkins]] *1984 - [[Donald D. Engen]], VAdm, USN (Ret) *1985 - [[Olle Klinker]] *1986 - Hon. [[John E. Krings]] *1987 - [[Burt Rutan]], [[Scaled Composites]] *1988 - [[Richard H. Truly]], Rear Admiral, USN *1989 - [[Irving L. Burrows]] *1990 - [[Robert P. Harper]] *1991 - [[Gordon E. Fornell]], LGen., USAF *1992 - [[William C. Bowes]], Vadm., USN and [[Peter W. Odgers]], MGen, USAF (Ret) *1993 - [[Tony LeVier|A. W. "Tony" LeVier]] *1994 - [[Per E. Pellebergs]] *1995 - [[Stephan A. Hanvey]] *1996 - [[Sean C. Roberts]], [[National Test Pilot School]] *1997 - [[Frank D. Robinson]] *1998 - [[J. Kenneth Higgins]] *1999 - Pete Reynolds *2000 - Sir [[Charles Masefield]] *2001 - [[Joseph Wendell Dyer, Jr.]], Vice Admiral (USN) / NASA / iRobot *2002 - [[Phil Schultz]] *2003 – [[Rogers E. Smith]], EADS *2004 – [[Burt Rutan]] *2005 - [[Robert C. Ettinger]], [[Northrop Grumman]] Unmanned Systems *2006 - [[Terry E. Tomeny]], [[Eclipse Aviation]] *2007 - [[Robert Crippen|Robert L. Crippen]] *2008 - [[M. Lynn Hanks]], Army Technical Test Center *2009 - [[Louis H. Knotts]], [[Calspan]] Corporation *2010 - Dennis P. O'Donoghue, The Boeing Company *2011 - Joseph E. Sweeney, Lockheed Martin *2012 - [[Doug Shane]], Scaled Composites *2013 - Charles T. Burbage, Lockheed Martin *2014 - George E. Cooper, Charter Member *2015 - Harold R. Gaston, [[Gulfstream Aerospace]] *2016 - Jeffrey A. Wieringa, The Boeing Company *2017 - William Gray, [[U.S. Air Force Test Pilot School]] *2018 - Mike Carriker, The Boeing Company

{{EngvarB|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Jelina-Berlow Rahman | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = 220px | alt = | caption = | native_name = জলিনা রহমান | native_name_lang = bn | birth_name = Jelina Rahman | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1980|1|4}} | birth_place = [[Bangladesh]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | residence = [[Glasgow]], Scotland | nationality = British | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Strathclyde]] | occupation = Solicitor | years_active = 2009–present | employer = | organization = J R Rahman Solicitors | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | home_town = [[London Borough of Barnet|Barnet]], London, England | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | spouse = Matthew Berlow | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | module = | website = {{URL|jrrahman.co.uk/}} | footnotes = }}
'''Jelina Rahman-Berlow''' ([[Name at birth|née]] '''Rahman'''; {{lang-bn|রহমান}}; born 4 January 1980) is a British solicitor whose practice J R Rahman Solicitors specialises in human rights, asylum, family and immigration legal advice and assistance.
==Early life== Rahman was born in [[Bangladesh]], came to the United Kingdom when she was eight months old and was brought up in [[London Borough of Barnet|Barnet]], London where she attended [[Queen Elizabeth's School for Girls]]. In 1998, at the age of 18, she moved to [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]]<ref name="theguardian">{{cite news |last=MacLeod|first=Murdo|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/audioslideshow/2014/jul/25/scotland-stories-scottish-independence-audio-slideshow|title=Scotland stories: Jelina Berlow-Rahman, human rights lawyer|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=25 July 2014|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> to pursue a degree in [[Bachelor of Laws|law]]<ref name="bbcasiannetwork">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01rg093|title=The British Bangladeshi Power and Inspiration List 2014|publisher=[[BBC Asian Network]]|date=2 February 2014|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> at the [[University of Strathclyde]].
Rahman's paternal uncle fought in [[World War II]] as a seaman. Rahman's father came to the UK at the age of 15 and started his own restaurant, and now has a restaurant in [[Wimbledon, London|Wimbledon]].<ref name="theguardian"/>
In 1997, at the age of 17, Rahman was diagnosed with [[systemic lupus erythematosus]] (lupus), a chronic autoimmune illness which left her with scarred facial skin and inflamed kidneys. In 2005, at the age of 26, her kidneys failed and she was on [[dialysis]] at [[Glasgow Royal Infirmary]] three days a week for four years. Rahman was on [[chemotherapy]] for two years. In December 2009, at the age of 29, she received a [[Kidney transplantation|kidney transplant]].<ref name="theguardian"/><ref name="bbcasiannetwork"/><ref name="journalonline2">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.journalonline.co.uk/News/1006796.aspx|title=Glasgow solicitor named business hero|work= |location= |publisher=''The Journal''|date=3 July 2009|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="dailyrecord">{{cite news |last=Silvester|first=Norman|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/exclusive-legal-eagle-runs-law-1039597|title=Exclusive: Legal eagle runs law firm from hospital bed|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]''|date=18 October 2009|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref>
==Career== Rahman required continuing hospital treatment since she qualified as a solicitor in December 2008.<ref name="journalonline2"/> In 2009, she opened her own law firm J R Rahman Solicitors.<ref name="bbcasiannetwork"/> She runs the firm single-handed, combining the roles of lawyer, receptionist, secretary and accountant while continuing with her dialysis treatment.<ref name="journalonline2"/>
In 2009, J R Rahman Solicitors was listed in the Top 100 Business at the [[Barclays]] Trading Places Awards, a Government-backed national awards which honours for people who turn their lives around by choosing to start up a business.<ref name="journalonline2"/> In the same year, it was awarded Up and Coming Law Firm of the Year at The Law Awards of Scotland.<ref name="thelawawards">{{cite web|url=http://www.thelawawards.com/pages/winners2009|title=2009 Winners|publisher=The Law Awards of Scotland|date=2009|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> In October 2009, legal watchdogs gave permission for Rahman to work on cases and see clients while undergoing treatment.<ref name="dailyrecord"/>
==Awards== In 2005, Rahman, whilst working as a working in the Asylum Department at Livingstone Brown, Glasgow, she won the Empower Scotland Social Equality and Justice Award.<ref name="journalonline1">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.journalonline.co.uk/Magazine/50-12/1002533.aspx|title=Young solicitor's Empower award|work= |location= |publisher=''The Journal''|date=12 December 2005|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> In 2008, she was named as one of the 30 Under 30 promising lawyers in Scotland.<ref name="firmmagazine">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.firmmagazine.com/jelina-rahman-scoops-business-award/|title=Jelina Rahman scoops business award|work= |location= |publisher=''The Firm''|date= |accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> In 2013, she was awarded Best Professional in Business at the Scottish Asian Business Awards.<ref name="theasianworld">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.theasianworld.co.uk/index.php/nominees-for-8th-annual-scottish-asian-business-awards-are-revealed/|title=Nominees for 8th annual Scottish Asian Business Awards are revealed|work= |location= |publisher=''Asian World''|date=25 November 2013|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="ethnicnow">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.ethnicnow.com/channels/business/press-release/20/7798/nominees-for-8th-annual-scottish-asian-business-awards-are-revealed.html|title=Nominees for 8th annual Scottish Asian Business Awards are revealed|work= |location= |publisher=''Ethnic Now''|date=25 November 2013|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="asianimage">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.asianimage.co.uk/news/business/10870763.print/|title=Scottish Asian Business Awards winners|work= |location= |publisher=''Asian Image''|date=12 December 2013|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="asiansuk">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.asiansuk.com/scottish-asian-business-awards-finalists/|title=Scottish Asian Business Awards Presented by the Bank of Scotland Winners 2013|work= |location= |publisher=''AsiansUK''|date=December 2013|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="theasianbusinessawards">{{cite web |url=http://www.theasianbusinessawards.info/scotland/2013.html|title=2013 Winners|publisher=The Scottish Asian Business Awards|date=December 2013|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="heraldscotland">{{cite news |last=Wright|first=Scott|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/business/people/high-flyers-honoured-at-eighth-scottish-asian-business-awards-ceremony.22933814|title=High flyers honoured at eighth Scottish Asian Business Awards ceremony|work= |location=Glasgow|publisher=''[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]''|date=12 December 2013|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> In January 2014, she was named among the ''[[British Bangladeshi Power & Inspiration 100]]''<ref name="sundaymail">{{cite news |last=Silvester|first=Norman|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Dialysis+lawyer%27s+power+award.-a0358093256|title=Dialysis Lawyer's Power Award|work= |location=Glasgow|publisher=''[[Sunday Mail (Scotland)|Sunday Mail]]''|date=9 February 2014|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> for demonstrating success and inspiration.<ref name="bdnews24">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2014/01/30/uk-bangladeshis-who-inspire|title=UK Bangladeshis who inspire|work= |location=Bangladesh|publisher=''[[Bdnews24.com]]''|date=30 January 2014|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="theasians2">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.theasians.co.uk/story/20140123_bbp_honor_2014|title=British Bangladeshi to Honor 2014 Contributions|work= |location= |publisher=''The Asians''|date=23 January 2014|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="britbangla24">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.britbangla24.com/beta/british-bangladeshi-power-inspiration-launch-of-the-2014-list-and-the-peoples-choice/|title=British Bangladeshi Power & Inspiration – Launch of The 2014 List and The List "People's Choice"|work= |location= |publisher=''BritBangla24''|date=4 November 2013|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="eastlondonadvertiser">{{cite news |last=Barnett|first=Adam|url=http://www.eastlondonadvertiser.co.uk/news/top_100_british_bangladeshis_list_to_be_revealed_by_cllr_abdal_ullah_1_3237927|title=Top 100 British Bangladeshis list to be revealed by Cllr Abdal Ullah|work= |location=London|publisher=''[[East London Advertiser]]''|date=23 January 2014 |accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="theasians3">{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.theasians.co.uk/story/20140123_bbp_honor_2014|title=Chosen to Inspire, British Bangladeshi List Revealed|work= |location= |publisher=''The Asians''|date=5 February 2014|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Rahman is a [[Muslim]] and is married to Matthew Berlow (born 1970) who is a fellow lawyer and is [[Jewish]].<ref name="theguardian"/>
==See also== * [[British Bangladeshi]] * [[List of British Bangladeshis]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{Facebook|jelina.rahman|Jelina Berlow-Rahman}} * [http://www.jrrahman.co.uk/ J R Rahman Solicitors website] * [http://www.matthewberlowcriminallawyer.co.uk/ Matthew Berlow Criminal Lawyer website]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = | honorific_suffix = | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = circa 1839 | birth_place = [[Bishop's Stortford]], [[Hertfordshire]], England | death_date = {{Death date|1903|09|27|df=y}} | death_place =[[Parnell, New Zealand|Parnell]], [[Auckland]], New Zealand | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = British | other_names = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = {{Plainlist| * Businessman * [[Ironsand]]s entrepreneur }} | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | television = | religion = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | awards = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> }}
'''John Chambers''' (c. 1839 – 27 September 1903) was a British citizen who became a New Zealand businessman and [[ironsand]]s entrepreneur.
==Early life== He was born in [[Bishop's Stortford]], [[Hertfordshire]], England in about 1839<ref name="DNZB Chambers">{{DNZB|title=John Chambers|first= Peter|last= Lowe|id=2c14|accessdate=23 April 2017}}</ref> and arrived in New Zealand in 1866.<ref name=RSNZIaO1918>{{cite journal |title=New Zealand Ironsands: an Historical Account of an Attempt to Smelt Ironsands at Onehunga in 1883, Art. XXIV |url=http://rsnz.natlib.govt.nz/volume/rsnz_50/rsnz_50_00_002640.pdf|journal=Transactions and Proceedings of the Royal Society of New Zealand|author=Evan Parry|year=1918|volume=50|issue=Art. XXIV|pages=223–230|accessdate=20 July 2012}}</ref>
==Steel production in Onehunga== Chambers arrived in New Zealand in 1866 and realised that the ironsands on the beaches of [[Taranaki Region|Taranaki]] had [[Iron#Industrial production|iron production]] potential.<ref name=RSNZIaO1918/> The area takes its name from [[Mount Taranaki]], a volcano that rises above the beaches. Chambers twice tried to further international interest in the resources of the sands, but was thwarted at first by the lack of interest and [[smelting]] difficulties.<ref name=RSNZIaO1918/> He tried in 1876, when he approached smelters in the UK and US, but a general lack of interest produced only a few laboratory test smelts. In 1886 John Parry managed to persuade [[Henry Bessemer|Sir Henry Bessemer]] to experiment with the sands; the results were promising, though Bessemer was in his twilight years and unable to continue with development.<ref name=RSNZIaO1918/>
Chambers attended the [[Centennial Exposition|Philadelphia Exhibition]] of 1876, which proved unsuccessful; America had plentiful iron-ore resources that were cheap to smelt and so no interest was shown. Before leaving the US, Chambers heard about a smelting process invented by Joel Wilson of [[Dover, New Jersey]], which proved promising. Chambers formed a company with Guy H. Gardner and bought the New Zealand rights to the patent.<ref name=RSNZIaO1918/> Wilson sent one of his men, W. H. Jones, to New Zealand to demonstrate the process and help manage the smelting once the furnace was built. This resulted in a furnace being built in the [[Onehunga]] suburb of [[Auckland]], New Zealand.<ref name=TeAra>{{cite web|title=Iron and steel – Attempts to extract iron|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/iron-and-steel/2|work=Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|publisher=New Zealand Government|accessdate=20 July 2012|author=Fleur Templeton|page=2|date=28 September 2010}}</ref> Work was completed in February 1883 at a cost of £500, with its first steel produced on 27 February of that year using sand from North Head of Manukau Heads under a sixty-year contract from the New Zealand government.<ref name=RSNZIaO1918/>
However, the company ceased trading after a series of events led to a gradual reduction in quality of the steel produced. Jones got drunk in Onehunga and argued with one of their bricklayers in December 1883. Jones shot and killed the man and was sentenced to 14 years hard labour.<ref name=RSNZIaO1918/> The company tried to carry on but Edmund Otway, Jones' successor, was taken ill and died in June 1884. His successor was an iron-master from the [[River Clyde#Industrial growth|Clyde]] region of [[Scotland]], James McAndrew,<ref name=RSNZIaO1918/> who tried his best to carry on against mounting problems with the [[Smelting|de-oxidation]] part of the process. Production from the ironsands was eventually discontinued, as no-one was able to produce the same quality of iron as Jones had managed,<ref name=TeAra/> and the company resorted to producing [[wrought iron]] from scrap metal. This was a much reduced profit margin and eventually the shareholders were left with debts of £20,000 and the works were broken up and shipped to China.<ref name=RSNZIaO1918/>
==Later life== Chambers continued in various other iron-related companies and other businesses around the Auckland region, including gold-mining, eventually taking a position as manager of T. and S. Morrin & Son. Chambers started a company with his son in 1892, John Chambers and Son, importing mining equipment and other products; the company became a [[limited company]] in 1898.<ref name="DNZB Chambers"/>
Chambers died in 1903 in the [[Parnell, New Zealand|Parnell]] suburb of Auckland.<ref name="DNZB Chambers"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chambers, John}} [[Category:1903 deaths]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:English emigrants to New Zealand]] [[Category:Steel companies of New Zealand]] [[Category:Date of birth unknown]]
