revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Karel Janeček | honorific_suffix = | image = Janeček_Karel_2014_Hanna_Jon.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|07|26}} | birth_place = [[Plzeň]], [[Czechoslovakia]]
{{small|(now [[Czech Republic]])}} | residence = | nationality = [[Czechs|Czech]] | other_names = | citizenship = | education = [[Charles University in Prague]]
[[Bradley University]]
[[Carnegie Mellon University]] | occupation = [[mathematician]]; [[entrepreneur]] | years_active = | employer = | organization = Karel Janeček Foundation; Democracy 2.1 | agent = | known_for = anti-[[Corruption#Government.2FPublic Sector|corruption]] campaign; [[philanthropy]] | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | spouse = Mariem Mhadhbi {{small|(2015–present)}} | partner = Lilia Khousnoutdinova {{small|(2017–present)}} | children = 4 | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | website = [http://www.kareljanecek.com kareljanecek.com] | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Karel Janeček''' (born 26 July 1973 at [[Plzeň]], [[Czechoslovakia]]) is a [[Czechs|Czech]] [[mathematician]], [[entrepreneur]], anti-[[Corruption#Government.2FPublic Sector|corruption]] campaigner and author of voting system [[Democracy 2.1]] and online game President 21. ==Education== Janeček graduated from the Faculty of [[Mathematics]] and [[Physics]] of [[Charles University in Prague]] in the field of [[Probability]] and [[Mathematical Statistics]].[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=115284062&privcapId=23712517 Executive Profile], ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]'' He is an [[MBA]] in [[Finance]] graduate of [[Bradley University]], [[Peoria, Illinois]], USA, and a [[Ph.D.]] graduate in the field of [[Mathematical Finance]] of [[Carnegie Mellon University]] in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]], USA. ==Academia== During the period 2007-2013, Janeček lectured at the Faculty of Mathematics and Physics of Charles University in Prague. He specializes in [[optimal control]] in [[mathematical finance]]. Janeček has authored and co-authored several research articles in scientific journals in the area of applied [[stochastic calculus]], where his work has numerous citations, such as "Optimal investment with high-watermark performance fee," ''SIAM Journal on Control and Optimization'', 2012; "Futures trading with transaction costs," ''Illinois Journal of Mathematics'', 2010; "Asymptotic analysis for optimal investment and consumption with transaction costs," ''Finance and Stochastics'', 2004; and others. ==Business== From 1998 to 2000, Janeček worked as a mathematical analyst for the [[hedge fund]] Market Research Ltd, and from 2004 to 2005, served as Researcher in the [[Austrian Academy of Sciences]]. On the basis of his experience, he started the firm RSJ Algorithmic Trading.[http://www.radio.cz/en/section/one-on-one/businessman-and-anti-corruption-pioneer-karel-janecek-whistle-blowing-is-a-brave-thing-to-do "Businessman and anti-corruption pioneer Karel Janeček: Whistle-blowing is a brave thing to do"], [[Radio Prague]], 28 March 2011 ==Anti-corruption campaign== {{More|Corruption in the Czech Republic}} According to media reports, by 2013, the Czech government was "buffeted" by a series of corruption scandals that have threatened to bring it down.[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/28/world/europe/foes-want-czech-leader-prosecuted-over-amnesty.html?_r=0 "Foes Want Czech Leader Prosecuted Over Amnesty"], by [[Dan Bilefsky]], ''[[The New York Times]]'', 27 February 2013 After [[Václav Klaus]], then president of the republic, in his last days in office, granted [[amnesty]] to a number of people accused of [[corruption]], Janeček financed the publishing of online videos and newspaper advertisements urging Czechs to sign a [[petition]] calling Klaus to account. The signatures were published on a website called "High Treason" in [[Czech language|Czech]]. The movement convinced 28 Senators to back a proposal in the [[Senate of the Parliament of the Czech Republic|Senate]] for the [[Constitutional Court of the Czech Republic]] to undertake [[high treason]] proceedings against Klaus.[http://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2013/03/01/milliardaire-et-croise-anticorruption_1841515_3210.html "Karel Janecek, milliardaire et croisé anticorruption"], by Martin Plichta, ''[[Le Monde]]'', 1 March 2013 (in [[French language|French]]) Klaus, who was eventually not charged by the Supreme Court, had previously stated he did not regret the amnesty, and on an official visit to [[Slovakia]] dismissed the move as "political games." ==Political reform== In 2012, he proposed a new electoral system primarily based on a minus vote, i.e. the possibility to vote against a candidate. The idea was promoted as a part of the Positive Evolution project. In May 2013, Janecek created the electoral system [[Democracy 2.1]] or D21[https://www.d21.me/en/ Democracy 21] website which, he argues, will bring about a major improvement comparable to "an upgrade from DOS to Windows". The main effect of D21 lies in the use of multiple votes - each voter has twice as many votes than the number of seats available to winners. More concretely, for the elections to the Chamber of Deputies, he designed two-mandate districts in which voters could use four votes, with the possibility to use one minus vote.[http://praguewandering.com/2013/12/06/lessons-from-the-blackjack-table/ "Billionaire Mystifies Public as He Tries to Fight Corruption with Math"], ''Prague Wandering'', 6 December 2013 ==Sponsorship== The Karel Janeček Benevolent Fund for Support of Science and Research was established in 2010 (renamed as Neuron Fund for Support of Science in 2013) a non-profit organisation, which promotes the idea of benefactors supporting the science and research in the Czech Republic.[http://www.nfneuron.cz/en/about-us/ Neuron Fund for Support of Science] Neuron has supported a number of scientists and their projects through grants worth over 13 million [[Czech koruna|Czech crowns]].Approximately [[United States dollar|$]] 600,000 ==Gambling== [[File:SBA_diskette.jpg|thumb|right|150px|
SBA [[floppy disk]]
]] Janeček, in the 1990s, and after playing the game in various [[casino]]s in the United States and elsewhere, created a [[simulation software]] for [[Advantage gambling|advantage play]] in [[Blackjack]], which he marketed under the brand "Statistical Blackjack Analyzer."[http://www.sba21.com/Details.html SBA website] The sim program has been praised by many gambling researchers.E.g. [[Don Schlesinger]]: "[Janeček]'sStatistical Blackjack Analyzer software was the original, all-purpose simulator, and it has come to be known as the standard against which all other such products are measured." [http://www.sba21.com/Reviews.html Reviews], SBA website[http://www.sba21.com/Reviews.html SBA sample reviews] He has acted as a consultant for the casino games industry, including the creators of [[Blackjack Switch]], which, before it became operational, was tested by Janeček-created software.[http://www.professional-poker.com/interviews/geoff-hall/blackjack-switch.htm "Blackjack Switch - interview with Geoff Hall"], ''Professional Poker''See [http://wizardofodds.com/games/blackjack/switch/ Blackjack Switch] at the [[Michael Shackleford|Wizard of Odds]] website for the game's analysis Janeček, along with Brett Harris, [[R. Michael Canjar|Mike Canjar]], Winston Yamashita, Pete Moss, [[Steven L. Heston|Kim Lee]], and other gambling theorists, contributed to the development of what has become known as "[[Gambling and information theory|optimal betting theory]]", and the discovery that it is possible to calculate a [[Card counting#Running counts versus True counts in Balanced counting systems|true count for unbalanced counting systems]] in casino Blackjack.[http://www.bjinsider.com/newsletter_112_unbalanced.shtml "The truth about unbalanced counts"] by Dr Brett Harris, ''Blackjack Insider'' He has regularly contributed articles in gambling-research websites, such as [[Stanford Wong]]'s BJ21.com.[http://bj21.com/bj_reference/pages/certaintyequivalentanalysis.shtml "Certainty Equivalent Analysis"] by Karel Janeček, bj21.com Janeček recommends treating the handling of advantage play "as just another [[Investment#In finance|investment]]".[http://www.bj21.com/bj_reference/pages/fluctuations.shtml "Fluctuations - A Personal Perspective"] by [[MathProf]], bj21.com, ==Personal life== In 2015, Janeček married for the second time. His wife was [[Demographics of Tunisia|Tunisian]] Mariem Mhadhbi, a [[structural engineering|structural engineer]] who studied at [[Mines ParisTech|L'École des Mines]], on [[AngelList]] and they have one child. Janeček has two daughters from his first marriage. Since October 2017, he is in a relationship with Lilia Khousnoutdinova, and they have a daughter.{{cite news |last=Herrmannová|first=Nela|date=4 June 2018 |title=Karel Janeček má se svou neoficiální ženou dceru, porod byl výjimečný|language=Czech|trans-title=Karel Janeček has a daughter with his unofficial wife, the birth was exceptional |url=https://revue.idnes.cz/karel-janecek-lilia-khousnoutdinova-porod-dite-dcera-isabella-p6g-/lidicky.aspx?c=A180604_101834_lidicky_nh |dead-url=no |work=Revue iDnes |location=Prague |access-date=1 December 2018}} ==See also== *[[Kelly criterion]] *[[Edward O. Thorp]] *[[Claude Shannon]] *[[Black–Scholes model]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.kareljanecek.com/cs-CZ/blog Personal blog] (in [[Czech language|Czech]]) *[http://ceskapozice.lidovky.cz/anti-corruption-campaigner-targeted-by-prague-underworld-p3a-/tema.aspx?c=A120131_150518_pozice_54979 "Anti-corruption campaigner ‘targeted’ by Prague underworld"], ''Česká Pozice'', 31 January 2012 {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Janecek, Karel}} [[Category:Czech businesspeople]] [[Category:1973 births]] [[Category:Czech mathematicians]] [[Category:Charles University in Prague alumni]] [[Category:Bradley University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Czech billionaires]]

revision.comment: /* top */HTTP→HTTPS for [[US State Department]], per [[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/Bender the Bot 8|BRFA 8]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Kearney & Company''' is a [[Certified Public Accountant|CPA]] firm established in 1985. It is headquartered in Alexandria, Virginia. It exclusively serves the [[federal government of the United States]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kearneyco.com/about.htm |title=Kearney & Company – About us |publisher=Kearney & Company |accessdate=12 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205163638/http://www.kearneyco.com/about.htm |archivedate= 5 December 2010 |df= }}</ref> Kearney & Company are the 'independent auditors' of the [[United States Department of State]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/150505.pdf |title=US Department of State 2010 Agency Financial Report (''vid''.p.62) |publisher=United States Department of State |accessdate=12 January 2011}}</ref>
==History of the company== Founded in 1985, in 2000 the company sold its commercial business to concentrate exclusively on the federal market.<ref name="SmartCEO">{{cite web |url=http://www.smartceo.com/ |title=Statement by Kearney & Company CEO in publication Washington SmartCEO Future 50 January 2011 p.64 |publisher=SmartCEO |accessdate=12 January 2011}}</ref> The next decade saw a major increase in the company's business, with annual revenues rising from $5 million to close to $75 million, and staff numbers from thirty to over four hundred.<ref name="SmartCEO"/> In December 2010 the company was named one of 'Washington's fastest-growing companies'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kearneyco.com/news_20101221.htm |title=Kearney & Company Named One of 2011's Fast Growth Companies |publisher=Kearney & Company |accessdate=12 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713142202/http://www.kearneyco.com/news_20101221.htm |archivedate=13 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> The company was also among [[Accounting Today]]'s '2010 Best Accounting Firms to Work For'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kearneyco.com/news_20100928.htm |title=Kearney & Company Named a "2010 Best Accounting Firms To Work For" by Accounting Today |publisher=Accounting Today (via Kearney & Company website since [[Accounting Today]] requires registration) |accessdate=12 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205164934/http://www.kearneyco.com/news_20100928.htm |archivedate= 5 December 2010 |df= }}</ref> In a statement of January 2011 CEO Edward F. Kearney opined "you must create your own demand by delivering … quality of service" and added "my style is to find the right players and give them space to do what they do well".<ref name="SmartCEO"/> Kearney & Company sponsor the Federal Accounting Handbook, and Ed Kearney is one of the co-authors of this manual.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0471739286.html |title=Federal Accounting Handbook: Policies, Standards, Procedures, Practices |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] |accessdate=12 January 2011}}</ref> Kearney & Company display on their corporate website the American insignia of the [[bald eagle]] and the [[United States Capitol]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kearneyco.com/ |title=Corporate Website – home page, about us |publisher=Kearney & Company |accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Auditor independence]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.kearneyco.com/ Kearney & Company corporate website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kearney and Company}} [[Category:Accounting firms of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Alexandria, Virginia]]

page.title: Major Field Test for Master of Business Administration

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
The '''Major Field Test for Master of Business Administration''' ('''MFT-MBA''') is a national [[standardized exam]] administered in the United States at the end of [[MBA]] programs. It is a [[comprehensive exam|comprehensive exit exam]]. The MFT-MBA aims to assess skills, knowledge, and reasoning ability within the domain of standard MBA curriculum.<ref name="Test Description">{{cite web |url=http://www.ets.org/s/mft/pdf/mft_mba_flyer.pdf |title=MFT MBA Flyer |publisher=Educational Testing Service |accessdate=November 2, 2014}}</ref> It is administered by Educational Testing Service (ETS) and has been used in the MBA programs of over 300 U.S. universities.<ref name="2013 4FMF Data Guide">{{cite web|url=http://www.ets.org/s/mft/pdf/acdg_mba.pdf |title=2013 Major Field Test Comparative Data Guide: Major Field Test for Master of Business Administration (MBA) |publisher=Educational Testing Service |accessdate=November 2, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122194137/http://www.ets.org/s/mft/pdf/acdg_mba.pdf |archivedate=January 22, 2014 }}</ref>
==History==
Most MBA programs require an exit exam to gauge students' comprehensive competency in the field of business management.<ref name="Study Guide">{{cite book| last =Phelan| first =James| title =The Major Field Test (MFT) for MBA Study Guide| publisher =Practical Application Publications| date =2014| location =Charleston, SC| isbn =0-9779773-5-8}}</ref> The MFT-MBA began being offered in 2002. It was developed nationally by leading educators to assess the skills of graduating MBA students.<ref name="Hays Post">{{cite news| last = Hays Post staff| title = FHSU MBA students bring in top scores on national MFT exam| newspaper = Hays Post| location = Fort Hays| publisher = Hays Post| date = May 16, 2015| url = http://www.hayspost.com/2015/05/16/fhsu-mba-students-bring-in-top-scores-on-national-mft-exam/| accessdate = October 4, 2015}}</ref> It is also used as a tool to compare business programs across the United States.<ref>{{cite news| last = Ingle| first = John | title = Midwestern State University on affordable list| newspaper = Times Record News| location = Witchita Falls| publisher = Journal Media Group| date = August 28, 2014| url = http://www.timesrecordnews.com/business/msu-on-affordable-list_23258473| accessdate = October 4, 2015}}</ref> ETS issues an updated test every 3–4 years in attempt to ensure high content validity.<ref name="Test Description" /> The most recent test forms are 4BMF (February 2005 - June 2009), 4FMF (September 2009 - June 2013), and 4JMF (September 2013 – present).<ref name="2009 4BMF Scoring Guide">{{cite web|url=https://www.ets.org/Media/Tests/MFT/pdf/MFT%20PDFs%202007/MBA4BMF.pdf |title=MBA 4BMF |publisher=Educational Testing Service |accessdate=November 2, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706064126/https://www.ets.org/Media/Tests/MFT/pdf/MFT%20PDFs%202007/MBA4BMF.pdf |archivedate=July 6, 2010 }}</ref><ref name="2013 4FMF Data Guide" /><ref name="2015 4JMF Data Guide">{{cite web|url=http://www.ets.org/s/mft/pdf/acdg_mba.pdf |title=2015 Major Field Test Comparative Data Guide: Major Field Test for Master of Business Administration (MBA) |publisher=Educational Testing Service |accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref>
==Content==
The MFT-MBA is based on MBA core curriculum. Unlike tests that are not aligned to anything but their own curriculum, the MFT-MBA emphasizes content validity. In order to display [[normative|normativity]] and ensure a consensus of what best reflects core curriculum, the content is constructed using results of a national curriculum survey. According to ETS, content experts from a diverse representation of higher education institutions (including Major Field Test users and nonusers) participate in this survey.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ets.org/mft/about/content/ |title=Test Content Overview |publisher=Educational Testing Service |accessdate=November 2, 2014}}</ref> Basing the exam on core curriculum makes it a level playing field exam, giving it meaningful results and enabling it to measure reasoning ability.<ref name="Honors Society">{{cite web |url=http://www.t10mba.com/admission |title=Membership Admission Requirements |publisher=T10 |accessdate=November 2, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Test Description" />
The test contains 124 [[multiple-choice]] questions. There are approximately 32 [[management]] questions, 31 [[marketing]] questions, 33 [[finance]] questions, and 28 [[management accounting|managerial accounting]] questions. Half of the questions require the strategic integration of two or more subject areas.<ref name="Test Description" /> In addition to factual knowledge, the test evaluates the student's abilities to interpret materials, understand relationships, and analyze and solve problems.<ref name="Hays Post" />
The Major Field Test for MBA can only be taken once.<ref name="Study Guide" /> The amount of time allotted for taking the test is three hours.<ref name="Test Description" /> It is taken on a computer. All exams are given at proctored facilities. Test takers are provided with scratch paper and pencils, but calculators are not permitted. All test questions present four answer options to choose from, only one of which is correct.<ref name="Study Guide" />
==Scoring== {| class="wikitable floatright" border="1" style="text-align:center; margin-left:1em; margin-right:0" |+Scoring summary<ref name="2015 4JMF Data
Guide" /> |- ! Percentile ! Score
|- | 99 | 284 |- | 91 | 271 |- | 80 | 264 |- | 70 | 258 |- | 62 | 254 |- | 50 | 249 |- | 42 | 245 |- | 31 | 239 |- | 20 | 233 |- | 10 | 227 |} A national scoring guide is issued annually. Scores range from 220-300. According to ETS, the overall scaled score on the MFT-MBA measures [[critical thinking]] and [[reason]]ing within the domain of standard MBA curriculum.<ref name="Test Description" /> The chart on the right provides a scoring summary at approximately every 10th percentile.
Form 4BMF was last used in 2009 making the 2009 scoring guide 4BMF's last scoring guide.<ref name="2009 4BMF Scoring Guide" /> Form 4FMF was last used in 2013 making the 2013 scoring guide 4FMF's last scoring guide.<ref name="2013 4FMF Data Guide" /> The 2015 scoring guide is the most up to date guide for 4JMF (the current test form).<ref name="2015 4JMF Data Guide" />
==Recognition of top performers==
Several universities such as Rutgers, LSU, and the University of Nebraska, Omaha give awards to recognize their students whom received top scores on the MFT-MBA.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://catalogs.rutgers.edu/generated/rbs_0507/pg4508.html |title=Awards for Graduating Students |publisher=Rutgers |accessdate=November 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://business.lsu.edu/news/releases/Pages/2012/05/LSU-Flores-MBA-Program-Holds-Honors-Banquet.aspx |title=LSU Flores MBA Program Holds Honors Banquet |publisher=LSU |date=May 4, 2012 |accessdate=November 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unomaha.edu/college-of-business-administration/mba/news/mft-article.php |title=Eleven MBA Graduates Receive UNO Distinguished MBA Scholar Award |publisher=University of Nebraska, Omaha |date=May 22, 2014 |accessdate=November 2, 2014}}</ref> The honors society T10 uses the MFT-MBA to recognize the top 10% of MBAs in the United States.<ref name="Honors Society" />
==Use by accreditation bodies==
The MFT-MBA and similar tests are used by business school accreditation bodies such as the International Assembly for Collegiate Business Education (IACBE), the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB), and the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP) to satisfy their assessment and accountability requirements.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://iacbe.org/oa-learning-measures.asp |title=Student Learning Assessment Measures |publisher=IACBE |accessdate=November 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iacbe.org/doc/new-program-accreditation-manual.doc |title=New Program Accreditation Manual |publisher=IACBE |accessdate=November 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smu.ca/academics/sobey/mba-cma-scores-high-on-major-field-test.html |title=Sobey School’s final MBA-CMA class demonstrates program excellence on standardized test |publisher=SMU |accessdate=August 2, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316003118/http://www.smu.ca/academics/sobey/mba-cma-scores-high-on-major-field-test.html |archivedate=March 16, 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washburn.edu/academics/college-schools/business/honors-awards/field-test.html |title=Major Field Test |publisher=Washburn |accessdate=August 2, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150307165151/http://www.washburn.edu/academics/college-schools/business/honors-awards/field-test.html |archivedate=March 7, 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.acbsp.org/resource/collection/EB5F486D-441E-4156-9991-00D6C3A44ED1/ACBSP_Standards_and_Criteria_-_Bacc-Grad.pdf |title=ACBSP Standards and Criteria for Demonstrating Excellence in Baccalaureate/Graduate Degree Schools and Programs |publisher=ACBSP |accessdate=September 18, 2017}}</ref>
==See also==
*[[Master of Business Administration]] *[[Comprehensive exam]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Examinations]] [[Category:Standardized tests in the United States]] [[Category:Business education]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=June 2018}} {{Cleanup infobox|date=June 2018}} {{Like résumé|date=June 2018}} {{third-party|date=June 2018}} }} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Mary Sally Matiella | image = Image:Mary Sallt Matiella.gif | order = 14th | office = Assistant Secretary of the Army (Financial Management and Comptroller) | term_start = February 16, 2010 | term_end = February 27, 2014 | president = [[Barack Obama]] | predecessor = [[Nelson M. Ford]] | successor = [[Robert M. Speer]] | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] }}
'''Mary Sally Matiella''' is a government official who served as the U.S. [[Assistant Secretary of the Army (Financial Management and Comptroller)]], holding office from February 16, 2010 until February 27, 2014, when she resigned and was succeeded by [[Robert M. Speer]].
In [[United States House of Representatives elections, 2018|2018]], Matiella is running as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] for the [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[Arizona's 2nd congressional district]].
==Biography==
Mary Sally Matiella (nee Garza), born in [[Three Rivers, Texas]], grew up as the child of migrant farmworkers. The family moved to Arizona when she was 6 months old. In between her junior and senior years at [[Pueblo High School (Tucson)|Pueblo High School]], she took a summer job at [[Davis-Monthan Air Force Base]] and met Airman Francisco Matiella, who would become her husband seven years later. Francisco suggested she go to college.
{{quote|"College was never on my family's radar. My older sister was the first high school graduate in the entire Garza family. They were just happy for us to graduate from high school."|}}
She earned a Regents’ Scholarship into the [[University of Arizona]], receiving a [[B.A.]] in 1973 and an [[M.B.A.]] in 1976. In 2013, she was named the University of Arizona, College of Education Alum of the year.<ref name="UAalum">https://uanews.arizona.edu/story/coe-alum-of-year-from-farmworker-family-to-pentagon-position</ref>
After college, she spent 1977-78 as a management analyst for the [[University of Texas at Austin]] and then spent 1978-80 working as an [[auditor]] for the [[Texas Department of State Health Services|Texas Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation]].
In 1980, Matiella began a long career as a civilian employee of the [[United States Armed Forces]]. She served as a budget analyst at [[Ramstein Air Base]] from 1980 to 1983; as a systems accountant for the [[United States Air Force]] Accounting Service, based in [[Denver]] from 1983 to 1986; and as a senior systems accountant at [[Fort Clayton]] from 1986 to 1989. She then returned to Denver, working at the [[Defense Finance and Accounting Service]] (DFAS) as a systems accountant 1989-92; a staff accountant 1992-94; and then as Director of the CFO Implementation Office 1994-95. From 1995 to 1998, she was Director of Accounting at the DFAS office in [[San Bernardino, California]]. She then moved to [[Washington, D.C.]] to become a staff accountant in the Office of the [[Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller)]], a position she held until 2001.
Matiella was in [[The Pentagon|the Pentagon]] at the time of the [[September 11 attacks|9/11 attack]].<ref name="UAalum"/>
Matiella became a member of the [[Senior Executive Service (United States)|Senior Executive Service]] in December 2001, becoming [[Chief Financial Officer]] of the [[United States Forest Service]]. There, she oversaw a $4 billion annual budget. She later served as Assistant Chief Financial Officer for Accounting for the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]] overseeing a $40 billion budget until her retirement in 2008.
[[Image:Westphal-Matiella.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[United States Under Secretary of the Army]] [[Joseph W. Westphal]] swears in Matiella as [[Assistant Secretary of the Army (Financial Management and Comptroller)]] on February 16, 2010.]] On November 23, 2009, [[President of the United States]] [[Barack Obama]] nominated Matiella to be [[Assistant Secretary of the Army (Financial Management and Comptroller)]]. After [[Senate confirmation]], she was sworn into office by [[United States Under Secretary of the Army]] [[Joseph W. Westphal]] on February 16, 2010.<ref>http://chapters.asmconline.org/mtvernon/files/2013/02/HON-Mary-Sally-Matiella-Bio.pdf</ref> During her service, she visited soldiers in Iraq.<ref>https://tucson.com/mary-sally-matiella/image_9c3becdc-ac32-5f52-b6f8-ff77e263b3a2.html</ref> She retired in 2014.
In 2017, Matiella announced she would challenge [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Congresswoman]] [[Martha McSally]] for her seat in the [[United States House of Representatives]] representing [[Arizona's 2nd congressional district]].<ref>https://tucson.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/mary-matiella-retired-assistant-secretary-of-army-enters-cd-race/article_245ed30b-1f41-5f0a-9d08-538d26c78860.html</ref> She is running as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], with support from the [[Justice Democrats]].<ref>https://justicedemocrats.com/Candidates</ref>
==External links== *{{C-SPAN|sallymatiella}} * [https://www.matiellaforcongress.com Matiella for Congress] - campaign website *[http://www.asafm.army.mil/offices/OfficeBio.aspx?OfficeCode=1000 Profile from the Dept. of the Army] *[http://www.army.mil/-news/2010/02/17/34542-army-swears-in-new-financial-management-secretary Story re. Matiella Being Sworn In]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Matiella, Mary Sally}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:University of Arizona alumni]] [[Category:United States Army civilians]] [[Category:United States Air Force personnel]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:Obama administration personnel]] [[Category:Women in finance]] [[Category:Women in the United States Air Force]] [[Category:Women in the United States Army]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Nelson Bunker Hunt | image = | image_size = 100x150px | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1926|2|22}} | birth_place = [[El Dorado, Arkansas]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2014|10|21|1926|02|22}} | death_place = [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], U.S. | occupation = {{unbulleted list|Oil, mining|Racehorse owner}} | nationality = [[United States|American]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | spouse = Caroline Lewis (m. 1951) | children = | parents = {{unbulleted list|[[H. L. Hunt]] and|Lyda Bunker}} | awards = {{plainlist| '''{{nowrap|[[Thoroughbred horse racing]]:}}''' *[[British flat racing Champion Owner]] (1973, 1974) *[[Eclipse Award for Outstanding Breeder]] (1985, 1987) }} }} '''Nelson Bunker Hunt''' (February 22, 1926 – October 21, 2014) was an [[United States|American]] [[Petroleum|oil]] company executive. He was a billionaire whose fortune collapsed after he and his brothers [[William Herbert Hunt|William Herbert]] and [[Lamar Hunt]]<ref name=NYT_obit_2014 /> tried to [[Cornering the market|corner the world market]] in [[silver]] but was prevented by government intervention.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news| last = Eichenwald| first = Kurt| title = 2 Hunts Fined And Banned From Trades| language = | publisher = ''New York Times''| date = December 21, 1989| url = https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/21/business/2-hunts-fined-and-banned-from-trades.html | accessdate = April 13, 2008 }}</ref> He was also a thoroughbred horse breeder.<ref name="HORSE1">{{cite book| last = Bowen| first = Edward L. | title = [[Legacies of the Turf|Legacies of the Turf: A Century of Great Thoroughbred Breeders]]| publisher = Eclipse Press| year = 2004 | location = Lexington, KY, United States| pages = 249–262| isbn = 1-58150-117-X}}</ref>
==Personal== Hunt was born in [[El Dorado, Arkansas]], but lived most of his life in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]].<ref name="JBS">{{cite web| title = Nelson Bunker Hunt | publisher = The John Birch Society, Inc.| url = http://www.jbs.org/about-jbs/nelson-bunker-hunt| accessdate = October 22, 2014}}</ref> He was the son of Lyda Bunker and [[Petroleum|oil]] [[Business magnate|tycoon]] [[H. L. Hunt]], who set up [[Placid Oil]], once one of the biggest independent oil companies,<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/oct/22/oil-baron-nelson-bunker-hunt-dies "Oil Baron Nelson Bunker Hunt Dies"] ''The Guardian'' 22 October 2014</ref> He had six siblings: [[Margaret Hunt Hill]] (1915–2007), H. L. Hunt III (1917–2005), [[Caroline Rose Hunt]] (1923–2018), Lyda Bunker Hunt (born and died in 1925), [[William Herbert Hunt]] (born 1929), and [[Lamar Hunt]] (1932–2006). He was married to Caroline Lewis Hunt of [[Ruston, Louisiana]] for 63 years until his death, and they had four children together.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.godreports.com/2014/11/one-of-the-richest-men-in-the-world-forced-into-bankruptcy-but-one-investment-brought-eternal-rewards/|title=One of the richest men in the world endured bankruptcy, but one investment brought eternal rewards {{!}} God Reports|website=blog.godreports.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-12}}</ref> In October 2014, Hunt died at the age of 88. He had cancer and dementia.<ref name=NYT_obit_2014>{{cite news |url=http://nyti.ms/1yWNeoS |title=Nelson Bunker Hunt, 88, Oil Tycoon With a Texas-Size Presence, Dies |date=October 22, 2014 |accessdate=February 26, 2016 |work=New York Times |author=McFadden, Robert D. }}</ref>
==Business career== Hunt played a very significant role in the discovery and development of the oil fields in [[Libya]], which were nationalized by [[Muammar Gaddafi]] in 1973.<ref name="Libya">{{Cite book| last = Greenwood| first = C. J.| title = International Law Reports| publisher = Cambridge University Press| year = 1984| volume = 66| page = 340| isbn = 0-521-46411-0}}</ref> This nationalization later resulted in the House of Lords decision in [[BP Exploration Co (Libya) v Hunt (No 2)]] [1983] 2 AC 352.
Hunt owned the [[Dallas]]-based Titan Resources Corporation, which is still involved in the exploration of oil in North Africa.<ref name=Bloomberg_2008>{{citation |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601116&sid=aRCsmu51x92A&refer=africa |title=Ethiopia, U.S. Billionaire's Titan Resources Signs Oil Accord'|author=McLure, Jason |work=Bloomberg |date=August 21, 2008}}</ref> He was chairman of Hunt Exploration and Mining Company (HEMCO).{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}
==Silver manipulation== {{main|Silver Thursday}} Beginning in the early 1970s, Hunt and his brothers William Herbert and Lamar began accumulating large amounts of silver. By 1979, they had nearly cornered the global market.<ref name="TEXAS">{{cite magazine| last = Gwynne| first = S. C.| title = Bunker Hunt|magazine= Texas Monthly| volume = 29 | issue = 9|page=78| publisher = Emmis Communications Corporation| location = Austin, Texas, United States| date = September 2001 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> In the last nine months of 1979, the brothers profited by an estimated $2 billion to $4 billion in silver [[speculation]], with estimated silver holdings of {{convert|100|e6ozt|kg}}.<ref name="Time1">{{cite magazine| title = Bunker Hunt's Comstock Lode |magazine=Time Magazine| volume = 115| issue = 2| publisher = Time Inc.| date = January 14, 1980|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,921789,00.html}}</ref>
Primarily because of the Hunt brothers' accumulation of the precious metal, prices of silver [[futures contract]]s and silver bullion rose from $11 an ounce in September 1979 to $50 an ounce in January 1980. Silver prices ultimately collapsed to below $11 an ounce two months later.<ref name="loe">{{cite report | url=http://loe.org/images/content/080919/Act1.pdf | title=The Accidental Hunt Brothers: How Institutional Investors Are Driving Up Food And Energy Prices | publisher=LOE | date=31 July 2008 | accessdate=26 February 2016 | pages=51 | author1=Masters, Michael W. | author2=White, Adam K.}}</ref> The largest single day drop in the price of silver occurred on "[[Silver Thursday]]."<ref name="NYT" /> In February 1985 the Hunt brothers were charged "with manipulating and attempting to manipulate the prices of silver futures contracts and silver bullion during 1979 and 1980" by the [[United States]] [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission]].<ref name="NYT" />
In September 1988 the Hunt brothers filed for bankruptcy under [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code]] largely due to lawsuits incurred as a result of their silver speculation.<ref name="NYT" />
In 1989, in a settlement with the CFTC, Nelson Bunker Hunt was fined US$10 million and banned from trading in the commodity markets as a result of civil charges of conspiring to manipulate the silver market.<ref name="NYT" /> This fine was in addition to a multimillion-dollar settlement to pay back taxes, fines and interest to the [[Internal Revenue Service]] for the same period. His brother{{which?|date=November 2018}} made a similar settlement.<ref name="NYT" />
==Politics== Nelson Bunker Hunt was extremely active in conservative political causes<ref name="Kingdom">{{Cite book| last = Tuccille| first = Jerome | title = Kingdom: The Story of the Hunt Family of Texas| publisher = Beard Books| year = 2004| page = 311 | isbn = 1-58798-226-9}}</ref> and was a member of the Council of the [[John Birch Society]].<ref name="JBS" />
Hunt also mentored [[Zahid Bashir]], former spokesman and press secretary to the Pakistani Prime Minister, in oil trading. He was one of the main sponsors of the conservative organization [[Western Goals Foundation]], founded in 1979 by General [[John K. Singlaub]], journalist John Rees, and Democratic Congressman from Georgia [[Larry McDonald]]. During the mid-1980s, he contributed almost half a million U.S. dollars to The National Endowment for the Preservation of Liberty (NEPL),<ref name="IranContraWalsh">{{Cite journal| last = Walsh| first = Lawrence E.| title = Final Report of the Independent Counsel for Iran/Contra Matters| volume = I: Investigations and Prosecutions| date = August 4, 1993| accessdate = July 5, 2008| url = https://fas.org/irp/offdocs/walsh/chap_13.htm}}</ref><ref name="CongressionalCommittee">{{Cite book | last =Hamilton | first =Lee H. | last2 =Inouye | first2 =Daniel K. | year = 1995 | title = Report of the Congressional Committees Investigating the Iran/Contra Affair | publisher =DIANE Publishing | pages = 93–94 | isbn = 0-7881-2602-4}}</ref> a conservative fundraising organization later heavily implicated in the [[Iran–Contra affair]].<ref name="IranContraNYT">{{Cite news| last = Berke| first = Richard L.| title =Investigators Say Group Raised $2 Million for Contra Arms Aid | newspaper = New York Times| date = April 9, 1987| accessdate = July 5, 2008| url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE5DB1739F93AA35757C0A961948260}}</ref> Hunt was past Chairman of the Board of the Bible Society of Texas and the past Chairman of, and significant contributor to [[Cru (Christian organization)|Campus Crusade for Christ International]]'s "Here's Life" Campaign (1976–1980),<ref name="Diamond">{{cite book| last = Diamond| first = Sara | title = Spiritual Warfare: The Politics of the Christian Right| publisher = South End Press| year = 1989 | location = Boston, USA|page=53| isbn = 0-89608-361-6}}</ref><ref name="Evangelicalism">{{Cite book| last =Harrington Watt| first =David | year =1991| title =A Transforming Faith: Explorations of Twentieth-century American Evangelicalism| publisher =Rutgers University Press| page =19 | isbn =0-8135-1717-6}}</ref> as well as providing a $3.5 million loan guarantee for the 1979 Campus Crusade film ''[[Jesus (1979 film)|Jesus]]''.<ref name="Time2">{{cite magazine| last = Van Biema| first = David| title = The Life of Jesus in 830 Languages|magazine=Time Magazine| volume = 161 | issue = 26|page=42| date = June 30, 2003}}</ref>
==Thoroughbred horse racing== In 1955, Hunt bought his first thoroughbreds and by the 1970s his breeding program had become one of the world's largest and most productive. Winner of the U.S. [[Eclipse Award for Outstanding Breeder]] in 1976, 1985, and 1987, he owned the {{convert|8000|acre|ha|adj=on}} Bluegrass Farm in [[Lexington, Kentucky]], and raced thoroughbreds in [[Europe]] and [[North America]]. Among his horses, Hunt bred or raced [[Vaguely Noble]], [[Dahlia (horse)|Dahlia]], [[Empery]], [[Youth (horse)|Youth]], [[Exceller]], [[Trillion (horse)|Trillion]], [[Glorious Song]], [[Dahar (horse)|Dahar]] and [[Estrapade (horse)|Estrapade]].<ref name="HORSE1" />
In 1973 and 1974, Hunt was the [[British flat racing Champion Owner]] and in 1976 won [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]].<ref name="HORSE1" />
The United States [[National Thoroughbred Racing Association]] (NTRA) awarded Hunt the title of "legendary owner-breeder".<ref name="HORSE2">{{cite web | title = Nelson Bunker Hunt| publisher = National Thoroughbred Racing Association| date = May 30, 2006| url = http://www.ntra.com/stats_bios.aspx?id=2142 | accessdate = April 13, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080201053009/http://www.ntra.com/stats_bios.aspx?id=2142 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = February 1, 2008}}</ref> Overall, Hunt bred 158 stakes winners and either bred or owned 25 champions.<ref name=bloodhorse_2005>{{citation |url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/26692/john-gaines-in-his-own-words |title=John Gaines in his own words |work=Blood-Horse |date=February 14, 2005}}</ref>
Hunt's bankruptcy forced him to liquidate his thoroughbred operations. A 1988 dispersal sale of 580 horses at [[Keeneland Sales]] brought in $46,911,800, at that time the highest amount in the history of thoroughbred auctions.<ref name="HORSE1" /> In 1999, he returned to thoroughbred ownership, spending a total of $2,075,000 on 51 juveniles and yearlings. At the time he said, "At my age, I don't plan to do any breeding or buy a farm, I just want to have some fun and try to get lucky racing."<ref name="HORSE2" />
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hunt, Nelson Bunker}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:American commodities traders]] [[Category:American businesspeople in the oil industry]] [[Category:American racehorse owners and breeders]] [[Category:Businesspeople in metals]] [[Category:Eclipse Award winners]] [[Category:Hunt family]] [[Category:People from El Dorado, Arkansas]] [[Category:Owners of Epsom Derby winners]] [[Category:Texas Republicans]] [[Category:John Birch Society members]] [[Category:The Hill School alumni]]

revision.text:
{{main|Productivity}}
This article is about the important technologies that have historically increased [[productivity]] and is intended to serve as the History section of [[Productivity]] from which it was moved.
Productivity in general is a ratio of output to input in the production of goods and services. Productivity is increased by lowering the amount of labor, capital, energy or materials that go into producing any given amount of economic goods and services. Increases in productivity are largely responsible for the increase in per capita living standards.
[[File:Mule-jenny.jpg|thumb|The [[spinning jenny]] and [[spinning mule]] (shown) greatly increased the productivity of thread manufacturing compared to the [[spinning wheel]].]]
==History== {{See also|History of technology}} Productivity improving technologies date back to antiquity, with rather slow progress until the late Middle Ages. Important examples of early to medieval European technology include the [[water wheel]], the [[horse collar]], the spinning wheel, the three-field system (after 1500 the four-field system—see [[Crop rotation]]) and the [[blast furnace]].<ref> {{cite book |title=Medieval Technology and Social Change |last1=White |first1= Lynn Townsend Jr. |authorlink= |year=1962 |publisher =Oxford University Press |location= |isbn= |pages= | postscript = <!--None-->}} </ref> All of these technologies had been in use in China, some for centuries, before being introduced to Europe.<ref> {{cite book |title=The Genius of China: 3000 years of science, discovery and invention |last1=Temple |first1= Robert |authorlink= |author2=Joseph Needham |year= 1986|publisher = Simon and Schuster |location=New York |isbn= |pages= | postscript = <Based on the works of Joseph Needham>}} </ref>
Technological progress was aided by literacy and the diffusion of knowledge that accelerated after the [[spinning wheel]] spread to Western Europe in the 13th century. The spinning wheel increased the supply of rags used for pulp in [[paper]] making, whose technology reached Sicily sometime in the 12th century. Cheap paper was a factor in the development of the [[movable type]] [[printing press]], which led to a large increase in the number of books and titles published.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Marchetti | first1 = Cesare | title =A Postmortem Technology Assessment of the Spinning Wheel: The Last 1000 Years, Technological Forecasting and Social Change, 13; pp. 91-93 | year = 1978 | url = http://www.cesaremarchetti.org/archive/scan/MARCHETTI-079.pdf | postscript = <!--None--> | ref = harv }}</ref><ref name ="Febvre-Martin1976">{{cite book |title=The Coming of the Book: The Impact of Printing, 1450-1800 |last1=Febvre |first1=Lucien |last2=Martin |first2=Henri-Jean |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1976|publisher= Verso|location= London and Borrklyn, NY|isbn=978-1-84467-633-0 |pages= |url= }}</ref> Books on science and technology eventually began to appear, such as the mining technical manual ''[[De Re Metallica]]'', which was the most important technology book of the 16th century and was the standard chemistry text for the next 180 years.<ref name="Musson & Robinson"> {{cite book |title=Science and Technology in the Industrial Revolution |last=Musson |author2=Robinson |year=1969 |publisher =University of Toronto Press |location= |isbn= |pages=26, 29}} </ref>
[[Francis Bacon]] (1561-1626) is known for the [[scientific method]], which was a key factor in the [[scientific revolution]]. Bacon stated that the technologies that distinguished Europe of his day from the Middle Ages were paper and printing, gunpowder and the magnetic compass, known as the [[four great inventions]]. The [[four great inventions]] important to the development of Europe were of Chinese origin.<ref name="Simon and Schuster">{{cite book |title=The Genius of China: 3000 years of science, discovery and invention |last1=Temple |first1= Robert |authorlink= |author2=Joseph Needham |year= 1986|publisher = Simon and Schuster |location=New York |isbn= |pages= | postscript = <Based on the works of Joseph Needham>}}</ref> Other Chinese inventions included the horse collar, cast iron, an improved plow and the seed drill. See also [[List of Chinese inventions]].
Mining and metal refining technologies played a key role in technological progress. Much of our understanding of fundamental chemistry evolved from ore smelting and refining, with ''[[De Re Metallica]]'' being the leading chemistry text for 180 years.<ref name="Musson & Robinson"/> Railroads evolved from [[minecart|mine carts]] and the first steam engines were designed specifically for pumping water from mines. The significance of the blast furnace goes far beyond its capacity for large scale production of cast iron. The blast furnace was the first example of [[continuous production]] and is a [[countercurrent exchange]] process, various types of which are also used today in chemical and petroleum refining. [[Hot blast]], which recycled what would have otherwise been waste heat, was one of engineering's key technologies. It had the immediate effect of dramatically reducing the energy required to produce pig iron, but reuse of heat was eventually applied to a variety of industries, particularly steam boilers, chemicals, petroleum refining and pulp and paper.
Before the 17th century scientific knowledge tended to stay within the intellectual community, but by this time it became accessible to the public in what is called "open science".<ref name="Mokyr 2004">{{ Cite web | last1 = Mokyr | first1 =Joel | authorlink1 = | title = Long Term Economic Growth and the History of Technology | year = 2004 | url = |pages=19–20 | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> Near the beginning of the Industrial Revolution came publication of the [[Encyclopédie]], written by numerous contributors and edited by [[Denis Diderot]] and [[Jean le Rond d'Alembert]] (1751–72). It contained many articles on science and was the first general encyclopedia to provide in depth coverage on the mechanical arts, but is far more recognized for its presentation of thoughts of the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]].
Economic historians generally agree that, with certain exceptions such as the [[steam engine]], there is no strong linkage between the 17th century scientific revolution (Descartes, Newton, etc.) and the Industrial Revolution.<ref name="Mokyr 2004"/> However, an important mechanism for the transfer of technical knowledge was scientific societies, such as The Royal Society of London for Improving Natural Knowledge, better known as the [[Royal Society]], and the Académie des Sciences. There were also technical colleges, such as the [[École Polytechnique]]. Scotland was the first place where science was taught (in the 18th century) and was where [[Joseph Black]] discovered [[heat capacity]] and [[latent heat]] and where his friend [[James Watt]] used knowledge of heat to conceive the [[Watt steam engine#Separate condenser|separate condenser]] as a means to improve the efficiency of the steam engine.<ref> {{cite book |title=Why Europe: |publisher = |location= |isbn= |pages= | postscript = <!--None-->}} </ref>
Probably the first period in history in which economic progress was observable after one generation was during the [[British Agricultural Revolution]] in the 18th century.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/british/empire_seapower/agricultural_revolution_01.shtml Mark Overton: Agricultural Revolution in England 1500–1850 (2011)]</ref> However, technological and economic progress did not proceed at a significant rate until the English Industrial Revolution in the late 18th century, and even then productivity grew about 0.5% annually. High productivity growth began during the late 19th century in what is sometimes call the [[Second Industrial Revolution]]. Most major innovations of the Second Industrial Revolution were based on the modern scientific understanding of [[chemistry]], [[Maxwell's equations|electromagnetic theory]] and [[thermodynamics]] and other principles known to profession of engineering.
==Major sources of productivity growth in economic history== [[File:burlaks walking.jpg|thumb|1900s photograph of [[burlaks|barge pullers]] on the Volga River. Pushing was done with poles and manual pulling using overhanging tree branches.<ref> {{cite book |title=A New Economic View of American History |last1=Atack |first1=Jeremy |last2=Passell |first2= Peter |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1994 |publisher =W.W. Norton and Co. |location= New York |isbn= 0-393-96315-2|page=156 | postscript = <!--None-->}} </ref> Horses were also used. ]]
=== New forms of energy and power=== Before the industrial revolution the only sources of power were water, wind and muscle. Most good water power sites (those not requiring massive modern dams) in Europe were developed during the medieval period. In the 1750s [[John Smeaton]], the "father of civil engineering," significantly improved the efficiency of the water wheel by applying scientific principles, thereby adding badly needed power for the Industrial Revolution.<ref> {{cite book |title=The Most Powerful Idea in the World: A Story of Steam, Industry and Invention |last1=Rosen |first1= William |authorlink= |year= 2012 |publisher = University Of Chicago Press |location= |isbn= 978-0226726342 |pages=137 | postscript = <!--None-->}} </ref> However water wheels remained costly, relatively inefficient and not well suited to very large power dams. [[Benoît Fourneyron]]'s highly efficient turbine developed in the late 1820s eventually replaced waterwheels. Fourneyron type turbines can operate at 95% efficiency and used in today's large hydro-power installations. Hydro-power continued to be the leading source of industrial power in the United States until past the mid 19th century because of abundant sites, but steam power overtook water power in the UK decades earlier.<ref>{{Harvnb|Hunter|year-1985|pp=}}</ref>
In 1711 a [[Newcomen steam engine]] was installed for pumping water from a mine, a job that typically was done by large teams of horses, of which some mines used as many as 500. Animals convert feed to work at an efficiency of about 5%, but while this was much more than the less than 1% efficiency of the early Newcomen engine, in coal mines there was low quality coal with little market value available. Fossil fuel energy first exceeded all animal and water power in 1870. The role energy and machines replacing physical work is discussed in Ayres-Warr (2004, 2009).<ref name="Ayres-Warr2004">{{Cite journal |last1 = Ayres |last2 = Warr |first1 = Robert U. |first2 = Benjamin |author1-link = |title = Accounting for Growth: The Role of Physical Work |year = 2004 |url = http://www.abundancedebunked.com/downloads/Ayres-TheRoleOfPhysicalWork.pdf |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170116171105/http://www.abundancedebunked.com/downloads/Ayres-TheRoleOfPhysicalWork.pdf |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2017-01-16 |postscript = <!--None--> |ref = harv }}</ref><ref name="Ayres-Warr2009"/>
While steamboats were used in some areas, as recently as the late 19th Century thousands of workers [[burlaks|pulled barges]]. Until the late 19th century most coal and other minerals were mined with picks and shovels and crops were harvested and grain threshed using animal power or by hand. Heavy loads like 382 pound bales of cotton were handled on hand trucks until the early 20th century. [[File:coaltub.png|right|frame|A young "drawer" pulling a coal tub along a mine gallery.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Dunn | first1 = James | author1-link = | title = From Coal Mine Upwards: or Seventy Years of an Eventful Life | year = 1905 | isbn=1-4344-6870-4 | url = | postscript = <The autobiography of James Dunn> }}James Dunn started working in a mine at age eight circa 1843 and describes work conditions and living conditions at the time </ref> [[Minecart]]s were more common than the skid shown. Railroads descended from minecarts. In Britain laws passed in 1842 and 1844 improved working conditions in mines.]]
Excavation was done with shovels until the late 19th century when steam shovels came into use. It was reported that a laborer on the western division of the Erie Canal was expected to dig 5 cubic yards per day in 1860; however, by 1890 only 3-1/2 yards per day were expected.<ref>{{cite book |title=Recent Economic Changes and Their Effect on Production and Distribution of Wealth and Well-Being of Society |last=Wells |first=David A. |year=1891 |publisher= D. Appleton and Co.|location= New York|isbn= 0-543-72474-3 |page=416 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=2V3qF4MWh_wC }}</ref> Today's large electric shovels have buckets that can hold 168 cubic meters and consume the power of a city of 100,000.<ref name = "Smil 2006"/>
[[Dynamite]], a safe to handle blend of [[nitroglycerin]] and [[diatomaceous earth]] was patented in 1867 by [[Alfred Nobel]]. Dynamite increased productivity of mining, tunneling, road building, construction and demolition and made projects such as the Panama Canal possible.
Steam power was applied to [[threshing machine]]s in the late 19th century. There were steam engines that moved around on wheels under their own power that were used for supplying temporary power to stationary farm equipment such as threshing machines. These were called ''road engines,'' and Henry Ford seeing one as a boy was inspired to build an automobile.<ref>{{ Cite book |last1= Ford |first1=Henry |author1-link= Henry Ford |last2=Crowther |first2=Samuel |title= My Life and Work: An Autobiography of Henry Ford |year= 1922 |url= http://www.gutenberg.org/catalog/world/readfile?fk_files=22786&pageno=45 }}</ref> Steam tractors were used but never became popular.
With internal combustion came the first mass-produced tractors ([[Fordson tractor|Fordson]] c. 1917). Tractors replaced horses and mules for pulling reapers and combine harvesters, but in the 1930s self powered combines were developed. Output per man hour in growing wheat rose by a factor of about 10 from the end of World War II until about 1985, largely because of powered machinery, but also because of increased crop yields.<ref name="MS & SJ">{{Cite journal | last1 = Moore | first1 = Stephen | last2 = Simon | first2 = Julian | author1-link = | title = The Greatest Century That Ever Was: 25 Miraculous Trends of the last 100 Years, The Cato Institute: Policy Analysis, No. 364 | date = Dec 15, 1999 | url = http://www.cato.org/pubs/pas/pa364.pdf | postscript = <!--None--> | ref = harv }}Fig. 13</ref> Corn manpower showed a similar but higher productivity increase. See below:[[Productivity improving technologies (historical)#Mechanized agriculture|Mechanized agriculture]]
One of the greatest periods of productivity growth coincided with the [[electrification]] of factories which took place between 1900 and 1930 in the U.S.<ref name="Ayres-Warr2004"/><ref name="Hunter 1991">{{cite book |title=A History of Industrial Power in the United States, 1730-1930, Vol. 3: The Transmission of Power |last=Hunter |first= Louis C. |authorlink= |author2=Bryant, Lynwood |year=1991 |publisher =MIT Press |location= Cambridge, Massachusetts, London |isbn=0-262-08198-9 |pages=}}</ref> See: ''[[Mass production#Factory electrification|Mass production: Factory electrification]]''
=== Energy efficiency=== In engineering and economic history the most important types of energy efficiency were in the conversion of heat to work, the reuse of heat and the reduction of friction.<ref name="Harvnb|Landes|year-1969|pp">{{Harvnb|Landes|year-1969|pp=}}</ref> There was also a dramatic reduction energy required to transmit electronic signals, both voice and data.
====Conversion of heat to work==== {{Main|Steam engine|Timeline of steam power|Thermal power station|Engine efficiency}} The early [[Newcomen steam engine]] was about 0.5% efficient and was improved to slightly over 1% by [[John Smeaton]] before [[Watt steam engine|Watt's]] improvements, which increased [[thermal efficiency]] to 2%. In 1900 it took 7 lbs coal/ kw hr.
Electrical generation was the sector with the highest productivity growth in the U.S. in the early twentieth century. After the turn of the century large central stations with high pressure boilers and efficient steam turbines replaced reciprocating steam engines and by 1960 it took 0.9 lb coal per kw-hr. Counting the improvements in mining and transportation the total improvement was by a factor greater than 10.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rosenberg|1982|pp=65}}</ref> Today's [[steam turbine]]s have efficiencies in the 40% range.<ref name="Ayres-Warr2009">[[Robert Ayres (scientist)|Robert U. Ayres]] and Benjamin Warr, ''The Economic Growth Engine: How useful work creates material prosperity'', 2009. {{ISBN|978-1-84844-182-8}}</ref><ref>[http://www.cuug.ab.ca/branderr/eeepc/017_coal.html] Graph of steam engine efficiencies</ref><ref name ="Smil2005"> {{cite book |title=Creating the Twentieth Century: Technical Innovations of 1867-1914 and Their Lasting Impact |last=Smil |first=Vaclav |year=2005 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford, New York |isbn= |pages= |url= }} </ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Ayres | last2 = Ayres | last3 =Warr | first1 = R. U. | first2 = L. W. | first3 =B. | author1-link = | title = Exergy, Power and Work in the U. S. Economy 1900-1998, Insead's Center For the Management of Environmental Resources, 2002/52/EPS/CMER | year = 2002 | url =http://flora.insead.edu/fichiersti_wp/inseadwp2002/2002-52.pdf | postscript = <!--None--> | ref = harv }}</ref> Most electricity today is produced by thermal power stations using steam turbines.
The Newcomen and Watt engines operated near atmospheric pressure and used atmospheric pressure, in the form of a vacuum caused by condensing steam, to do work. Higher pressure engines were light enough, and efficient enough to be used for powering ships and locomotives. Multiple expansion (multi-stage) engines were developed in the 1870s and were efficient enough for the first time to allow ships to carry more freight than coal, leading to great increases in international trade.<ref name="Wells1891">{{cite book |title=Recent Economic Changes and Their Effect on Production and Distribution of Wealth and Well-Being of Society |last=Wells |first=David A. |year=1891 |publisher= D. Appleton and Co.|location= New York|isbn= 0-543-72474-3 |pages= |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=2V3qF4MWh_wC }}</ref>
The first important diesel ship was the ''[[MS Selandia]]'' launched in 1912. By 1950 one-third of merchant shipping was diesel powered.<ref name="Williams 1993"/> Today the most efficient prime mover is the [[Wärtsilä-Sulzer RTA96-C|two stroke marine diesel engine]] developed in the 1920s, now ranging in size to over 100,000 horsepower with a [[thermal efficiency]] of 50%.<ref name="McNeil 1990 pp">{{Harvnb|McNeil|1990|pp=}}</ref>
Steam locomotives that used up to 20% of the U.S. coal production were replaced by diesel locomotives after World War II, saving a great deal of energy and reducing manpower for handling coal, boiler water and mechanical maintenance.
Improvements in steam engine efficiency caused a large increase in the number of steam engines and the amount of coal used, as noted by [[William Stanley Jevons]] in ''[[The Coal Question]]''. This is called the [[Jevons paradox]].
====Electrification and the pre-electric transmission of power==== {{Main|Electrification}} {{Details|Line shaft}} Electricity consumption and economic growth are strongly correlated.<ref name="Electricity in Economic Growth">{{cite book |title=Electricity in Economic Growth |last1=Committee on Electricity in Economic Growth Energy Engineering Board Commission on Engineering and Technical Systems National Research Council |year=1986 |publisher =National Academy Press |location= Washington, DC |isbn= 0-309-03677-1|pages=16, 40 |url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=900 | postscript = <Available as free .pdf download>}}</ref> Per capita electric consumption correlates almost perfectly with economic development.<ref> {{cite book |title=The Evolution of Progress: The End of Economic Growth and the Beginning of Human Transformation |last1=Paepke |first1= C. Owen |authorlink= |year= 1992|publisher =Random House |location= New York, Toronto |isbn= 0-679-41582-3|pages=109 | postscript = <!--None-->}} </ref> [[Electrification]] was the first technology to enable long distance transmission of power with minimal [[Losses in electrical systems|power losses]].<ref name = "Hunter&Bryant 1991"> {{cite book |title=A History of Industrial Power in the United States, 1730-1930, Vol. 3: The Transmission of Power |last1=Hunter |first1= Louis C. |last2=Bryant |first2=Lynwood |authorlink= |author3=Bryant, Lynwood |year=1991 |publisher =MIT Press |location= Cambridge, Massachusetts, London |isbn=0-262-08198-9 |page=}} </ref> Electric motors did away with [[line shaft]]s for distributing power and dramatically increased the productivity of factories. Very large central [[Thermal power station|power stations]] created economies of scale and were much more efficient at producing power than reciprocating steam engines.<ref name ="Ayres-Warr2004" /><ref name="Electricity in Economic Growth"/><ref name = "Hunter&Bryant 1991"/><ref name = "Ayers-Warr 2002">{{Cite journal | last1 = Ayres | last2 = Ayres| last3 =Warr| first1 = R. U.| first2 = L. W.| first3 =B.| author1-link =| title = Exergy, Power and Work in the U. S. Economy 1900-1998, Insead’s Center For the Management of Environmental Resources, 2002/52/EPS/CMER| year = 2002|url =http://econpapers.repec.org/article/eeeenergy/v_3a28_3ay_3a2003_3ai_3a3_3ap_3a219-273.htm}}</ref><ref name ="Ayres-Warr2006">{{Cite journal | last1 = Ayres | last2 = Warr | first1 = Robert U. | first2 = Benjamin | author1-link = | title = Economic growth, technological progress and energy use in the U.S. over the last century: Identifying common trends and structural change in macroeconomic time series, INSEAD | year = 2006 | url = http://www.helsinki.fi/iehc2006/papers2/Warr.pdf | postscript = <!--None--> | ref = harv }}</ref> Electric motors greatly reduced the capital cost of power compared to steam engines.<ref name = "Ayers-Warr 2002">{{Cite journal | last1 = Ayres | last2 = Ayres| last3 =Warr| first1 = R. U.| first2 = L. W.| first3 =B.| author1-link =| title = Exergy, Power and Work in the U. S. Economy 1900-1998, Insead’s Center For the Management of Environmental Resources, 2002/52/EPS/CMER| year = 2002|url =http://econpapers.repec.org/article/eeeenergy/v_3a28_3ay_3a2003_3ai_3a3_3ap_3a219-273.htm}}</ref>
The main forms of pre-electric power transmission were [[line shaft]]s, [[hydraulic power network]]s and pneumatic and wire rope systems. [[Line shaft]]s were the common form of power transmission in factories from the earliest industrial steam engines until factory electrification. Line shafts limited factory arrangement and suffered from high power losses.<ref name = "Hunter&Bryant 1991"/> Hydraulic power came into use in the mid 19th century. It was used extensively in the [[Bessemer process]] and for cranes at ports, especially in the UK. London and a few other cities had hydraulic utilities that provided pressurized water for industrial over a wide area.<ref name = "Hunter&Bryant 1991"/>
Pneumatic power began being used industry and in mining and tunneling in the last quarter of the 19th century. Common applications included rock drills and jack hammers.<ref name = "Hunter&Bryant 1991"/> Wire ropes supported by large grooved wheels were able to transmit power with low loss for a distance of a few miles or kilometers. Wire rope systems appeared shortly before electrification.<ref name = "Hunter&Bryant 1991"/>
====Reuse of heat==== Recovery of heat for industrial processes was first widely used as [[hot blast]] in [[blast furnace]]s to make pig iron in 1828. Later heat reuse included the Siemens-Martin process which was first used for making glass and later for steel with the [[open hearth furnace]]. (See: [[Productivity improving technologies (historical)#Iron and steel|Iron and steel]] below). Today heat is reused in many basic industries such as chemicals, oil refining and pulp and paper, using a variety of methods such as [[heat exchanger]]s in many processes.<ref>See various engineering texts on thermodynamics, heat transfer, distillation</ref> [[Multiple-effect evaporator]]s use vapor from a high temperature effect to evaporate a lower temperature boiling fluid. In the recovery of kraft pulping chemicals the spent black liquor can be evaporated five or six times by reusing the vapor from one effect to boil the liquor in the preceding effect. [[Cogeneration]] is a process that uses high pressure steam to generate electricity and then uses the resulting low pressure steam for process or building heat.
Industrial process have undergone numerous minor improvements which collectively made significant reductions in energy consumption per unit of production.
====Reducing friction==== Reducing friction was one of the major reasons for the success of railroads compared to wagons. This was demonstrated on an iron plate covered wooden tramway in 1805 at Croydon, U.K. <blockquote>“ A good horse on an ordinary turnpike road can draw two thousand pounds, or one ton. A party of gentlemen were invited to witness the experiment, that the superiority of the new road might be established by ocular demonstration. Twelve wagons were loaded with stones, till each wagon weighed three tons, and the wagons were fastened together. A horse was then attached, which drew the wagons with ease, six miles in two hours, having stopped four times, in order to show he had the power of starting, as well as drawing his great load.”<ref> {{cite book |title=Railroads of the United States, Their History and Statistics |last=Fling |first= Harry M. |year= 1868|publisher =John. E. Potter and Co. |location= Philadelphia |isbn= |pages=12, 13 | postscript = <!--None-->}} </ref></blockquote> Better lubrication, such as from petroleum oils, reduced friction losses in mills and factories.<ref>{{Harvnb|Landes|1969|pp=298–9}}</ref> Anti-friction bearings were developed using alloy steels and precision machining techniques available in the last quarter of the 19th century. Anti-friction bearings were widely used on bicycles by the 1880s. Bearings began being used on [[line shaft]]s in the decades before factory electrification and it was the pre-bearing shafts that were largely responsible for their high power losses, which were commonly 25 to 30% and often as much as 50%.<ref name = "Hunter&Bryant 1991"/>
====Lighting efficiency==== Electric lights were far more efficient than oil or gas lighting and did not generate smoke, fumes nor as much heat. Electric light extended the work day, making factories, businesses and homes more productive. Electric light was not a great fire hazard like oil and gas light.<ref name= "Nye 1990">*{{cite book |title= Electrifying America: Social Meanings of a New Technology|last=Nye |first=David E.|year=1990 |publisher= The MIT Press |location=Cambridge, MA, USA and London, England |isbn= |pages= |url= }}</ref>
The efficiency of electric lights has continuously improved from the first incandescent lamps to tungsten filament lights.<ref>{{Harvnb|Rosenberg|1982|pp=61}}</ref> The [[fluorescent lamp]], which became commercial in the late 1930s, is much more efficient than incandescent lighting. [[Light-emitting diode]]s or LED's are highly efficient and long lasting.<ref>[http://energy.gov/articles/history-light-bulb History of the Light Bulb]</ref>
=== Infrastructures === The relative energy required for transport of a tonne-km for various modes of transport are: pipelines=1(basis), water 2, rail 3, road 10, air 100.<ref name ="McNeil1990" />
====Roads==== Unimproved roads were extremely slow, costly for transport and dangerous.<ref name="Grübler"/> In the 18th century layered gravel began being increasingly used, with the three layer [[Macadam]] coming into use in the early 19th century. These roads were crowned to shed water and had drainage ditches along the sides.<ref name="Grübler"/> The top layer of stones eventually crushed to fines and smoothed the surface somewhat. The lower layers were of small stones that allowed good drainage.<ref name="Grübler"/> Importantly, they offered less resistance to wagon wheels and horses hooves and feet did not sink in the mud. Plank roads also came into use in the U.S. in the 1810s-1820s. Improved roads were costly, and although they cut the cost of land transportation in half or more, they were soon overtaken by railroads as the major transportation infrastructure.<ref name="Grübler"/>
====Ocean shipping and inland waterways==== Sailing ships could transport goods for over a 3000 miles for the cost of 30 miles by wagon.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = U.S. Government | title = U.S. Senate Committee | year =1834 |journal= American State Papers |volume= Misc II |issue= |page=287 |publisher=United States | postscript = < “A ton of goods could be brought 3000 miles from Europe for about $9, but for that same sum it could be moved only 30 miles in this country.”> | ref = harv }}</ref> A horse that could pull a one-ton wagon could pull a 30-ton barge. During the English or First Industrial Revolution, supplying coal to the furnaces at Manchester was difficult because there were few roads and because of the high cost of using wagons. However, canal barges were known to be workable, and this was demonstrated by building the [[Bridgewater Canal]], which opened in 1761, bringing coal from Worsley to Manchester. The Bridgewater Canal’s success started a frenzy of canal building that lasted until the appearance of railroads in the 1830s.<ref name ="McNeil1990"/><ref name="Grübler">{{Cite book | last1 = Grübler | first1 = Arnulf | author1-link = | title = The Rise and Fall of Infrastructures: Dynamics of Evolution and Technological Change in Transport | year = 1990 |publisher=Physica-Verlag |location= Heidelberg and New York |isbn= |pages= | url = http://www.iiasa.ac.at/Admin/PUB/Documents/XB-90-704.pdf | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref>
====Railroads==== {{see also|History of rail transport}} Railroads greatly reduced the cost of overland transportation. It is estimated that by 1890 the cost of wagon freight was U.S. 24.5 cents/ton-mile versus 0.875 cents/ton-mile by railroad, for a decline of 96%.<ref name ="Fogel1964">{{cite book |title=Railroads and American Economic Growth: Essays in Econometric History |last=Fogel |first=Robert W.|year=1964 |publisher=The Johns Hopkins Press |location=Baltimore and London |isbn= 0-8018-1148-1 |pages= |url= }} Cost is in 1890 gold standard dollars.</ref>
Electric street railways ([[tram]]s, trolleys or streetcars) were in the final phase of railroad building from the late 1890s and first two decades of the 20th century. Street railways were soon displaced by motor buses and automobiles after 1920.<ref>{{anchor|Slater}} {{ cite web | url = http://www.cliffslateralso.com/TQOrigin.pdf | title = General Motors and the Demise of Streetcars | author = Slater, Cliff | publisher = Transportation Quarterly | year = 1997 | pages = 45–66 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120425092145/http://www.cliffslateralso.com/TQOrigin.pdf | archivedate = 2012-04-25 | df = }}</ref>
====Motorways==== Highways with internal combustion powered vehicles completed the mechanization of overland transportation. When trucks appeared c. 1920 the price transporting farm goods to market or to rail stations was greatly reduced. Motorized highway transport also reduced inventories.
The high productivity growth in the U.S. during the 1930s was in large part due to the highway building program of that decade.<ref> {{cite book |title=A Great Leap Forward: 1930s Depression and U.S. Economic Growth |last1=Field |first1= Alexander J. |authorlink= |year= 2011 |publisher =Yale University Press |location= New Haven, London |isbn=978-0-300-15109-1 |pages= | postscript = <!--None-->}} </ref>
====Pipelines==== Pipelines are the most energy efficient means of transportation.<ref name ="McNeil1990" /> Iron and steel pipelines came into use during latter part of the 19th century, but only became a major infrastructure during the 20th century.<ref name="Grübler"/><ref>{{cite book |title=The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money & Power |last=Yergin |first= Daniel |year=1992 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |pages= |url= }}</ref> [[Centrifugal pump]]s and [[centrifugal compressor]]s are efficient means of pumping liquids and natural gas.
===Mechanization=== {{main|Mechanization}} [[File:Adriance reaper, 19th century illustration.jpg|thumb|[[Adriance Company|Adriance]] reaper, late 19th century]][[File:Batteuse 1881.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Threshing machine from 1881. Steam engines were also used instead of horses. Today both threshing and reaping are done with a [[combine harvester]].]]
====Mechanized agriculture==== The seed drill is a mechanical device for spacing and planting seed at the appropriate depth. It originated in ancient China before the 1st century BC. Saving seed was extremely important at a time when yields were measured in terms of seeds harvested per seed planted, which was typically between 3 and 5. The seed drill also saved planting labor. Most importantly, the seed drill meant crops were grown in rows, which reduced competition of plants and increase yields. It was reinvented in 16th century Europe based on verbal descriptions and crude drawings brought back from China.<ref name="Simon and Schuster"/> [[Jethro Tull (agriculturist)|Jethro Tull]] patented a version in 1700; however, it was expensive and unreliable. Reliable seed drills appeared in the mid 19th century.<ref>{{Harvnb|Temple|1986|pp=26}}</ref>
Since the beginning of agriculture threshing was done by hand with a [[flail]], requiring a great deal of labor. The [[threshing machine]] (ca. 1794) simplified the operation and allowed it to use animal power. By the 1860s threshing machines were widely introduced and ultimately displaced as much as a quarter of agricultural labor.<ref> {{cite book |title=A Farewell to Alms: A Brief Economic History of the World'' |last=Clark |first=Gregory |year=2007 |publisher =Princeton University Press |location= |isbn= 978-0-691-12135-2|pages=286 | postscript = <!--None-->}} </ref> In Europe, many of the displaced workers were driven to the brink of starvation. [[File:Claas-lexion-570-1.jpg|thumb|Harvesting oats in a [[Claas]] Lexion 570 combine with enclosed, air-conditioned cab with rotary thresher and laser-guided hydraulic steering]]
Before c. 1790 a worker could harvest 1/4 acre per day with a [[scythe]].<ref name="Wells1891"/> In the early 1800s the [[grain cradle]] was introduced, significantly increasing the productivity of hand labor. It was estimated that each of [[Cyrus McCormick|Cyrus McCormick's]] horse pulled [[reaper]]s (Ptd. 1834) freed up five men for military service in the U.S. Civil War.<ref name ="Hounshell1984"/> By 1890 two men and two horses could cut, rake and bind 20 acres of wheat per day.<ref name="Wells1891"/> In the 1880s the reaper and [[threshing machine]] were combined into the [[combine harvester]]. These machines required large teams of horses or mules to pull. Over the entire 19th century the output per man hour for producing wheat rose by about 500% and for corn about 250%.<ref name="MS & SJ"/>
Farm machinery and higher crop yields reduced the labor to produce 100 bushels of corn from 35 to 40 hours in 1900 to 2 hours 45 minutes in 1999.<ref name="Constable_Ch7">{{cite book |title= A Century of Innovation: Twenty Engineering Achievements That Transformed Our Lives, Chapter 7, Agricultural Mechanization |last=Constable |first=George |authorlink= |author2=Somerville, Bob |year=2003 |publisher=Joseph Henry Press|location=Washington, DC |isbn= 0-309-08908-5 |pages= |url= http://www.greatachievements.org/?id=2955}}</ref> The conversion of agricultural mechanization to internal combustion power began after 1915. The horse population began to decline in the 1920s after the conversion of agriculture and transportation to internal combustion.<ref name="Tractors">{{Cite web |last1=White |first1=William J. |authorlink1= |title=Economic History of Tractors in the United States |url=http://eh.net/encyclopedia/article/white.tractors.history.us |postscript= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024041712/http://eh.net/encyclopedia/article/white.tractors.history.us |archivedate=2013-10-24 |df= }}</ref> In addition to saving labor, this freed up much land previously used for supporting draft animals.
The peak years for tractor sales in the U.S. were the 1950s.<ref name="Tractors"/> There was a large surge in horsepower of farm machinery in the 1950s.
====Industrial machinery==== {{Details|Industrial Revolution}} {{Details|Second Industrial Revolution}} The most important mechanical devices before the Industrial Revolution were water and wind mills. Water wheels date to Roman times and windmills somewhat later. Water and wind power were first used for grinding grain into flour, but were later adapted to power [[trip hammer]]s for pounding rags into pulp for making paper and for crushing ore. Just before the Industrial revolution water power was applied to bellows for iron smelting in Europe. (Water powered blast bellows were used in ancient China.)
