revision.text:
{{Infobox FBI Ten Most Wanted |name=Semion Mogilevich |birth_name=Semion Yudkovich Mogilevich |image=SEMION MOGILEVICH.jpg |imagesize= |alt= |caption= |charge= *Fraud by Wire *[[Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act]] Conspiracy *[[Mail Fraud]] *Money Laundering Conspiracy *[[Money Laundering]] *[[Aiding and Abetting]] *[[Securities fraud]] *Filing False Registration With the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] *False Filings With the SEC *Falsification of Books and Records |alias=Seva Moguilevich
Semon Yudkovich Palagnyuk
Semen Yukovich Telesh
Simeon Mogilevitch
Semjon Mogilevcs
Shimon Makelwitsh
Shimon Makhelwitsch
Sergei Yurevich Schnaider |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1946|6|30}} |birth_place=[[Kiev]], [[Ukrainian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] |death_date= |death_place= |cause= |nationality=Ukrainian, Russian, Hungarian, Israeli |family= |height={{height|cm=168|}} |weight={{convert|130|kg|lbs|}} |occupation=Russian mafia boss, confidence trickster, businessman, and economist |residence=[[Moscow]], [[Russia]] |spouse=Katalin Papp |children= |conviction= |conviction_penalty= |conviction_status= |added_date=October 23, 2009 |caught_date= |remove_date=December 17, 2015 |number=494 |status=Removed }} '''Semion Yudkovich Mogilevich'''{{cite news |date=October 23, 2009 |url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20091023/156566239.html |title=FBI puts crime boss Mogilevich on Ten Most Wanted list |publisher=RIANOVOSTI |accessdate=March 29, 2014}} ({{lang-uk|Семе́н Ю́дкович Могиле́вич}}, ''Semen Yudkovych Mohylevych'' {{IPA-uk|sɛˈmɛn ˈjudkɔwɪtʃ mɔɦɪˈlɛwɪtʃ|}}; born June 30, 1946) is a Ukrainian-born, Russian [[organized crime]] boss, believed by European and United States federal law enforcement agencies to be the "[[Capo di tutti capi|boss of bosses]]" of most [[Russian Mafia]] syndicates in the world.{{cite book |authorlink=Misha Glenny |last=Glenny |first=Misha |year=2008 |title=McMafia: A Journey Through the Global Criminal Underworld |location=New York |publisher=Alfred A. Knopf |pages=72–73 |isbn=978-1-4000-4411-5 }} Mogilevich is believed to direct a vast criminal empire and is described by the FBI as "the most dangerous mobster in the world."{{cite book |title=Petrostate: Putin, Power, and the New Russia |first=Marshall I. |last=Goldman |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=New York |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-19-534073-0 }} He has been accused by the FBI of "weapons trafficking, contract murders, extortion, drug trafficking, and prostitution on an international scale."{{cite web| url = http://www.slate.com/blogs/crime/2013/08/05/semion_mogilevich_fbi_ten_most_wanted_list_this_obese_mob_boss_is_twice.html| title = This Obese Mob Boss Is Twice the Villain Whitey Bulger Ever Was| author = Peters, Justin| date = August 5, 2013| accessdate = April 4, 2014| publisher = Slate.com}} Mogilevich's nicknames include "Don Semyon" and "The Brainy Don" (because of his business acumen).{{cite web|url=http://www.amw.com/fugitives/case.cfm?id%3D68944 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100316103215/http://www.amw.com/fugitives/case.cfm?id=68944 |archivedate=2010-03-16 |df= }} According to US diplomatic cables, he is said to control [[RosUkrEnergo]], a company actively involved in [[Russia–Ukraine gas disputes]], and a partner of [[Raiffeisen Bank]].According to Ukrainian Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] "we have no doubts whatsoever that the man named Mogilevich is behind the whole operation called RosUkrEnergo," see [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/panorama/6121508.stm The High Price of Gas] by [[BBC News]]. Mogilevich has denied through a lawyer any links to RosUkrEnergo, see [https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE56Q0JT20090727 Russia frees crime boss wanted by U.S.] by [[Reuters]]. He lives freely in [[Moscow]], and has three children. He is most closely associated with the [[Solntsevskaya Bratva]] crime group. Political figures he has close alliances with include [[Yury Luzhkov]], the former Mayor of Moscow, [[Dmytro Firtash]] and [[Leonid Derkach]], former head of the [[Security Service of Ukraine]].[http://www.jamestown.org/programs/edm/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=33941&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=166&no_cache=1 Ukraine, Vanco Energy and the Russian Mob], Eurasia Daily Monitor, 16 September 2008.Rachkevych, Mark (3 December 2010). [http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/91986/ "U.S. Official: Austrian Bank's Ties to RosUkrEnergo Suspicious"]. ''[[Kyiv Post]]''. Retrieved 14 December 2010. [[Oleksandr Turchynov]], who was designated as acting President of Ukraine in February 2014, appeared in court in 2010 for allegedly destroying files pertaining to Mogilevich.{{cite web| url = https://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/new-and-conflicting-details-emerge-over-mogilevich-92521.html| title = New and conflicting details emerge over Mogilevich’s alleged involvement in nation| author = Byrne, Peter| date = December 10, 2010| accessdate = April 8, 2014| publisher = kyivpost.com}} Defector [[Alexander Litvinenko]], shortly before his assassination, claimed that Mogilevich had allegedly a "good relationship" with [[Vladimir Putin]] since the 1990s.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/11364900/Listen-Alexander-Litvinenkos-apparent-warning-before-his-death.html Listen: Alexander Litvinenko's apparent warning before his death] By Lyndsey Telford, Edward Malnick and Claire Newell12:00PM GMT 23 Jan 2015 ==Biography== === Early life === Mogilevich was born in 1946 to a [[History of the Jews in Kiev|Jewish]] family in [[Kiev]]'s [[Podil|Podol]] neighborhood.Block, Alan A.; Weaver, Constance A. (2004) ''All Is Clouded by Desire: Global Banking, Money Laundering, and International Organized Crime''. Greenwood Publishing Group: Westport. {{ISBN|0-275-98330-7}} p. 1 His first significant fortune derived from scamming fellow Russian Jews eager to emigrate to countries including the United States and Israel; Mogilevich made deals to buy their assets, sell them for fair market value, and forward the proceeds. Instead he simply sold the assets and pocketed the proceeds. He served two terms in prison, of 3 and 4 years, for currency-dealing offenses.{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/1998-05-26/news/the-most-dangerous-mobster-in-the-world/full/|title=The Most Dangerous Mobster in the World|author=Robert I. Friedman|date=22 January 2008|work=villagevoice.com}} Beginning in the early 1980s, according to the FBI, Mogilevich was the key money-laundering contact for the [[Solntsevskaya Bratva]].{{cite web |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/143586/trumps-russian-laundromat-trump-tower-luxury-high-rises-dirty-money-international-crime-syndicate |title=Trump's Russian Laundromat; How to use Trump Tower and other luxury high-rises to clean dirty money, run an international crime syndicate, and propel a failed real estate developer into the White House. |author=[[Craig Unger]] |date=July 13, 2017 |website=Newrepublic.com |access-date=5 November 2017}} === Hungary === In early 1991, Mogilevich moved to Hungary and married his Hungarian girlfriend Katalin Papp. He had three children with her, and obtained a Hungarian passport. Living in a fortified villa outside [[Budapest]], he continued to invest in a wide array of enterprises, including buying a local armament factory, "Army Co-Op," which produced anti-aircraft guns.{{cite news| url = http://www.budapestsun.com/full_story.asp?ArticleID=%7B6493A16274FB46438BE680B4A19AEE86%7D&From=News| title = Article about activities in Hungary| accessdate = October 7, 2006| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120302065332/http://www.budapestsun.com/full_story.asp?ArticleID=%7B6493A16274FB46438BE680B4A19AEE86%7D&From=News| archivedate = March 2, 2012| df = }} In 1994, the Mogilevich group obtained control over [[Inkombank]], one of the largest private banks in Russia,{{cite web| url = http://russianlaw.org/Morgent1.htm| title = New York court document, 2000| accessdate = October 7, 2006| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070701095350/http://russianlaw.org/Morgent1.htm| archivedate = July 1, 2007| df = }} in a secret deal with bank chairman [[Vladimir Vinogradov]], getting direct access to the world financial system. The bank collapsed in 1998 under suspicions of money laundering.{{cite news | url = http://moscowtelegraph.com/mt050801.htm | title = Moscow Telegraph on investigation of Inkombank management |publisher=Moscow Telegraph| accessdate = October 7, 2006}} === Czech raid === In May 1995, a meeting in [[Prague]] between Mogilevich and [[Sergei Mikhailov (businessman)|Sergei Mikhailov]], head of the [[Solntsevskaya bratva|Solntsevo group]], was raided by [[Czech Republic|Czech]] police. The occasion was a birthday party for one of the deputy Solntsevo mafiosi. Two hundred partygoers (including dozens of [[prostitute]]s) in the restaurant "U Holubů", owned by Mogilevich, were detained and 30 expelled from the country.{{cite web| url = http://www.mvcr.cz/2003/casopisy/pol/0409/rusko_info.html| title = Journal of the Czech ministry of interior, article about Russian mafias| accessdate = 2006-10-07| language = Czech| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070114193653/http://www.mvcr.cz/2003/casopisy/pol/0409/rusko_info.html| archivedate = 2007-01-14| df = }} Police had been tipped off that the Solntsevo group intended to execute Mogilevich at the party{{cite web| url = http://www.volny.cz/vyber_cr/vyber2/pribeh_muze.html| title = Biography of Mogilevich| work = [[Lidové Noviny]]| accessdate = 2006-10-07| language = Czech| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20041109154007/http://www.volny.cz/vyber_cr/vyber2/pribeh_muze.html| archivedate = 2004-11-09| df = }} over a disputed payment of $5 million. But Mogilevich never showed up and it is believed that a senior figure in the Czech police, working with the [[Russian mafia]], had warned him.Glenny (2008), ''Op. cit.'', pp 71–72. Soon, however, the Czech Interior Ministry imposed a 10-year entry ban on Mogilevich, while the Hungarian government declared him ''[[persona non grata]]'' and the British barred his entry into the UK, declaring him "one of the most dangerous men in the world."Glenny (2008), ''Op. cit.'', pp 75. === Toronto exchange === In 1997 and 1998, the presence of Mogilevich, Mikhailov and others associated with the [[Russian Mafia]] behind a public company trading on the [[Toronto Stock Exchange]] (TSX), YBM Magnex International Inc., was exposed by Canadian journalists. On May 13, 1998, dozens of agents for the FBI and several other U.S. government agencies raided YBM's headquarters in [[Newtown, Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Newtown, Pennsylvania]]. Shares in the public company, which had been valued at $1 billion on the TSX, became worthless overnight.{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/static/events/panorama/transcripts/transcript_06_12_99.txt | title = BBC Panorama's "The Billion Dollar Don"| accessdate = 2007-09-15 | work=BBC News}} === Money laundering and tax evasion === Until 1998, Inkombank and [[Bank Menatep]] participated in a US$10 billion [[money laundering]] scheme through the [[Bank of New York]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cdi.org/russia/johnson/3516.html##4|title=Overview of the money laundering schemes|accessdate=October 7, 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061005054117/http://www.cdi.org/russia/johnson/3516.html|archivedate=October 5, 2006|df=}}''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', September 5, 1999: "A Scheme for Ducking Taxes May Be a Key In Russia Money Probe"{{cite web|url=http://financialservices.house.gov/banking/92299ren.htm |title=Testimony of Thomas Renyi, CEO of the bank, 1999|accessdate=October 7, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060929094324/http://financialservices.house.gov/banking/92299ren.htm |archivedate=2006-09-29}}{{cite web|url=http://russianlaw.org/bridge3.htm|title=Senior manager of BoNY indicted, 2001|accessdate=2006-10-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814044808/http://russianlaw.org/bridge3.htm|archivedate=2007-08-14|df=}} Mogilevich was also suspected of participation in large-scale tax fraud, where untaxed heating oil was sold as highly taxed car fuel – one of the greatest scandals that broke around 1990–1991. Estimates are that up to one-third of fuels sold went through this scheme, resulting in massive tax losses for various countries of [[Central Europe]] (Czech Republic, Hungary, Slovakia and Poland).{{cite web|url=http://web.volny.cz/noviny/zdomova/clanek/~volny/IDC/124259/volby-by-nyni-vyhrala-cssd.html|title=Overview of fuels scandal|work=[[Lidové Noviny]]|accessdate=2006-10-07|language=Czech}} In the Czech Republic the scandal is estimated to have cost the taxpayers around 100 billion CZK (≈US$5 billion)[http://www.novinky.cz/domaci/40954-podvody-s-lto-zrejme-prisly-stat-na-100-miliard.html Podvody s LTO zřejmě přišly stát na 100 miliard] (Czech) and involved, besides others, murders and assassination attempt of a journalist writing about the problem.[http://www.epravo.cz/top/clanky/nelegalni-obchody-s-lto-prinesly-danove-uniky-i-vrazdy-28351.html?mail Nelegální obchody s LTO přinesly daňové úniky i vraždy] (Czech) In 2003, the United States [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] put Mogilevich on the "Wanted List" for participation in the scheme to defraud investors in Canadian company YBM Magnex International Inc. Frustrated by their previous unsuccessful efforts to charge him for [[arms trafficking]] and [[prostitution]], they had now settled on the large-scale fraud charges as their best hope of running him to ground. He was, however, considered to be the most powerful Russian mobster alive.Glenny (2008), ''Op. cit.'', pg 77. In a 2006 interview, former Clinton administration anti-organized-crime czar Jon Winer said: "I can tell you that Semion Mogilevich is as serious an organized criminal as I have ever encountered and I am confident that he is responsible for [[contract killing]]s." Mogilevich was arrested in Moscow on January 24, 2008, for suspected [[tax evasion]].{{cite news |author=Guy Faulconbridge |date=January 25, 2008 |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsMaps/idUSL2537376820080125 |publisher=Reuters |title=Russia detains crime boss wanted by FBI |accessdate=March 29, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article3253243.ece|title=Login|work=timesonline.co.uk}} His bail was placed, and he was released on July 24, 2009. On his release, the Russian interior ministry stated that he was released because the charges against him "are not of a particularly grave nature".{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20090727/155636705.html|title=Suspects in Arbat Prestige case released with travel ban|date=27 July 2009|work=rian.ru}}[https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE56Q0JT20090727 Russia frees crime boss wanted by U.S.], [[Reuters]] (July 27, 2009) {{ill|Ivan Fursin|uk|Фурсін Іван Геннадійович}} has been closely linked to Mogilevich.{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/mueller-reveals-new-manafort-link-to-organized-crime |title=Mueller Reveals New Manafort Link to Organized Crime |author=Betsy Woodruff |date=2 November 2017 |website=[[TheDailyBeast.com]] |access-date=5 November 2017}} === FBI Ten Most Wanted list === On October 22, 2009, he was named by the FBI as the [[FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives, 2000s|494th fugitive to be placed]] on the [[FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives|Ten Most Wanted list]].{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/page2/oct09/mogilevich_102109.html |title=FBI — New Top Ten - Global Con Artist |work=FBI |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101008000445/http://www.fbi.gov/page2/oct09/mogilevich_102109.html |archivedate=2010-10-08 |df= }} In December 2015 he was removed from the list. The FBI indicated he no longer met list criteria, for reasons relating to living in a country with which the United States does not maintain an [[Extradition#Extradition treaties or agreements|extradition treaty]].Babay, Emily (December 17, 2015) [http://www.philly.com/philly/news/20151218_Philly_fugitive_bumped_off_FBI__Most_Wanted__list.html Philly fugitive bumped off FBI 'Most Wanted' list] ''Philadelphia Inquirer''. Retrieved January 16, 2016. In spite of the warrants issued against him, he still lives freely in Moscow, according to the FBI.{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/topten/semion-mogilevich/view|title=FBI — SEMION MOGILEVICH|work=FBI}} As to Mogilevich himself, government law enforcement agencies from throughout the world had by then been trying to prosecute him for over 10 years. But he had, in the words of one journalist, "a knack for never being in the wrong place at the wrong time".Glenny (2008), ''Op. cit.'', pg 76. Both Mogilevich and his associate Mikhailov ceased to travel to the west in the late 1990s. ==See also== *[[Felix Sater]] *[[Russian mafia]] *[[Solntsevskaya Bratva]] ==References== {{ibid|date=June 2018}} {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/topten/semion-mogilevich Mogilevich's FBI Top 10 Most Wanted Fugitive Alert] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110110090957/http://www.amw.com/fugitives/brief.cfm?id=68944 Mogilevich's profile on ''America's Most wanted''] *[https://www.fbi.gov/congress/congress03/ashley103003.htm US Senate testimony of FBI Assistant Director, includes Mogilevich] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/static/events/panorama/transcripts/transcript_06_12_99.txt "The Billion Dollar Don"] (Transcript of BBC Panorama documentary on activities in gas, YBM Magnex etc., incl. interview w. Mogilevich) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060715131914/http://www.heuni.fi/uploads/v2t9skuki.pdf Papers from Annual Conference of the European Society of Criminology, Helsinki, 2003] (PDF, describes the YBM Magnex scheme) *[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article3253243.ece Semyon Mogilevich, the 'East European mafia boss', captured in Moscow] *https://archive.is/20130102222242/http://www.forbes.com/2010/05/13/bin-laden-joaquin-guzman-dawood-ibrahim-business-world-most-wanted_slide_5.html {{FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives by year}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mogilevich, Semion}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Confidence tricksters]] [[Category:FBI Ten Most Wanted Fugitives]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted on fraud charges]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted on organised crime charges]] [[Category:Mob bosses]] [[Category:Russian businesspeople]] [[Category:Russian fraudsters]] [[Category:Ukrainian fraudsters]] [[Category:Ukrainian Jews]] [[Category:Ukrainian money launderers]] [[Category:People from Kiev]] [[Category:Russian mob bosses]] [[Category:Russian mobsters]] [[Category:Ukrainian businesspeople]] [[Category:Ukrainian mobsters]] [[Category:University of Lviv alumni]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Underlinked|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} The '''Small Business Development Corporation''' (SBDC) is an independent statutory authority, established in 1984<ref>The West Australian, 2014.</ref> under the Small Business Development Corporation Act 1983 by the [[Government of Western Australia]].
The primary role of the SBDC is to encourage, promote, facilitate and assist the establishment, growth and development of small business in Western Australia.<ref>http://www.smallbusiness.wa.gov.au.</ref> This is achieved by providing education and skill development programs, and advice and guidance to small business owners on the establishment, development and expansion of their businesses.
The SBDC communicates with the small business sector directly as well as liaising with industry and business associations to exchange information and provide support and assistance to their members. The SBDC also provides advice and support to Western Australia's Minister for Small Business on matters impacting the sector, including the effect of government policy and legislation on small business. Through these avenues, the SBDC helps to raise public awareness of the importance of small business to the economy and the community.<ref>http://www.smallbusiness.wa.gov.au.</ref>
In addition, the SBDC investigates any matters impacting small businesses, and advises small business on the means of obtaining financial assistance. The SBDC also maintains an information centre with a comprehensive range of business resources and provides a comprehensive range of business workshops for small business operators, existing and potential.
The current Minister for Small Business in Western Australia is Paul Papalia<ref>http://www.parliament.wa.gov.au/parliament/memblist.nsf/WAllMembersFlat/Papalia,+Paul?opendocument</ref> in the [[McGowan Ministry]].
==References== {{Reflist}} * http://www.smallbusiness.wa.gov.au * http://www.parliament.wa.gov.au/Parliament/Memblist.nsf/WAllMembersFlat/Papalia,+Paul?opendocument * ''SBDC 30th anniversary''. The West Australian (Perth, WA), 7 May 2014, Business News, p. 4
[[Category:Government agencies of Western Australia]] [[Category:Economy of Western Australia]] [[Category:Small business]]

{{Infobox person | name = Louis Richard Sosthenes Behn | image = Sosthenes Behn.jpg | caption = | birth_date = January 30, 1884 | birth_place = [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|St. Thomas]], [[Danish West Indies]] (now [[U.S. Virgin Islands]]) | death_date = {{death date and age|1957|06|6|1884|01|30}} | death_place = New York | occupation = Co-founder of the [[Puerto Rico Telephone Company]] and [[ITT Corporation]] | salary = | networth = | spouse = Margaret Behn | children = Edward John Behn, Margaret Cecilia Ertman, William Charles Behn | parents = Wilhelm Behn, Louisa Behn | signature = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Sosthenes Behn''' (January 30, 1884 – June 6, 1957) was an American businessman widely known for founding [[ITT Corporation|ITT]]. He held the rank of lieutenant colonel in the U.S. Army.
==Biography== ===Early years=== Sosthenes Behn was born in the island of [[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|St. Thomas]], then part of the [[Danish West Indies]]. His ancestry was [[Danes|Danish]] on his paternal side, and [[French people|French]] on his maternal side.
Behn served in the [[United States Army]] and was commissioned a Captain, Signal Corps, on June 19, 1917. He later achieved the rank of Lieutenant Colonel, having served with distinction during World War I. Behn served with the American Expeditionary Force (AEF) in France until February 1919. He was given command of the 232nd Field Signal Battalion, [[Château-Thierry]], [[Saint-Mihiel]], Argonne. In recognition of his meritorious service during the war he was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Medal (U.S. Army)|Distinguished Service Medal]] (DSM).
===Puerto Rico Telephone Company and ITT=== After his return from military service, Colonel Behn co-founded the [[Puerto Rico Telephone Company]] which eventually spawned ITT<ref>Morales Cortés, Ramón. [http://www.vii.org/papers/puer.htm Telecommunications in Puerto Rico] (paper). New York, USA: ''Virtual Institute of Information''.</ref> Under his direction ITT was granted the [[monopoly]] of telephone service in [[Spain]] ([[Telefónica|Compañía Telefónica Nacional de España]]) in 1924,<ref>García-Algarra, Javier: [https://www.scribd.com/doc/53101811/The-American-Influence-in-Telefonica%E2%80%99s-Public-Relations-Strategyduring-the-20%E2%80%99s-and-30%E2%80%99s "The American influence in Telefónica's public relations strategy during the 20s and 30s"], IEEE HISTELCON 2010</ref> and purchased the international division of [[Western Electric]].
According to Anthony Sampson's book ''[[The Sovereign State of ITT]]'', one of the first American businessmen Hitler received after taking power in 1933 was Sosthenes Behn, then the CEO of ITT, and his German representative, Henry Mann. [[Antony C. Sutton]], in his book ''Wall Street and the Rise of Hitler'', makes the claim that ITT subsidiaries made cash payments to [[Schutzstaffel|SS]] leader [[Heinrich Himmler]].
ITT, through its subsidiary [[C. Lorenz AG]] of [[Berlin]], owned 25% of [[Focke-Wulf]], the German aircraft manufacturer, builder of some of the most successful [[Luftwaffe#Interwar period|Luftwaffe]] [[fighter aircraft]]. In addition, Sutton’s book uncovers that ITT owned Dr. Erich F. Huth GmbH (Signalbau Huth, Berlin), which made [[radio]] and [[radar]] parts that were used in equipment going to the [[Wehrmacht]].
Behn, along with his brother, [[Hernan Behn|Hernan]], built the ''Two Brothers Bridge'' —''Puente Dos Hermanos'' in [[Spanish (language)|Spanish]]— in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]]. The bridge links the districts of [[Condado, Puerto Rico|Condado]] and [[Old San Juan, Puerto Rico|Old San Juan]].
Colonel Behn and [[Ludwig Roselius]], founder of the company [[KAFFEE HAG]], owned 74% of German aircraft manufacturer Focke-Wulf after the company reconstitution in 1936. [[Barbara Goette]] referred to Colonel Behn as a huge global player.<ref>Leidig, Ludwig. Bombshell sbpra, 2013, {{ISBN|978-1-62516-346-2}}</ref> Sosthenes Behn met with Hitler on 3/8/1933 and in 1936 there was a high-level meeting in Berlin where it was proposed that Behn through ITT gain 50% of [[Focke-Wulf]] and oust [[Café HAG]] completely, but after Barbara Goette intervened with Hitler, Ludwig Roselius' life was spared and he became majority shareholder in Focke-Wulf with 46% and a massive capital injection occurred.<ref>The Office of Military Government US Zone in Post-War Germany 1946-1949, declassified per Executive Order 12958, Section 3.5 NND Project Number: NND 775057 by: NND Date: 1977.</ref>
During the war, all of ITT's German holdings were put under Nazi control. These included a minority share in airplane manufacturer Focke-Wulf, which ITT had acquired through its contacts with German financier [[Kurt Baron von Schröder]]. After the end of the war, the US authorities returned these assets to their rightful US owner.
Behn appointed [[Gerhard Westrick]] to the board of Focke-Wulf after the reconstitution in 1936. He was ITT's corporation chairman in Germany. After Pearl Harbour, at meetings with Baron Kurt von Schröder and Behn in Switzerland, Westrick nervously admitted he had run into a problem. Wilhelm Ohnesorge, the elderly minister in charge of post offices, who was one of the first fifty Nazi party members, was strongly opposed to ITT's German companies continuing to function under New York management in time of war. Behn told Westrick to use Schröder and the protection of the Gestapo against Ohnesorge. In return, Behn guaranteed that ITT would substantially increase its payments to the Gestapo through the Circle of Friends. A special board of trustees was set up by the Nazis to cooperate with Behn and his thirty thousand staff in Occupied Europe. Ohnesorge savagely fought these arrangements and tried to obtain the support of Himmler. However, Schröder had Himmler's ear, and so, of course did his close friend and associate Walter Schellenberg. Ohnesorge appealed directly to Hitler and condemned Westrick as an American sympathiser. However, Hitler realized the importance of ITT to the German economy and proved supportive of Behn.
In 1943, ITT became majority shareholder of Focke-Wulf Flugzeugbau GmbH with 29% due to Ludwig Roselius' Kaffee HAG share falling to 27% after he died on May 15.<ref>Dieter Pfliegensdörfer; Volker Bergmann; Willi Elmers; Manfred Fittkau; Michael Jung; Michael Wolf; Wolfgang Günther. Wellblech & Windkanal. Arbeit und Geschäfte im Bremer Flugzeugbau von den Anfängen 1909 bis heute. Steintor, 1989, {{ISBN|3926028513}}</ref>
===Death=== Behn died on 6 June 1957.

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Multiple issues | {{Orphan|date=June 2013}} {{unreliable sources|date=May 2012}} {{self-published|date=May 2012}} {{more citations needed|date=May 2012}} {{one source|date=May 2012}} {{external links|date=May 2012}} {{COI|date=June 2012}} }} {{Infobox website | name = The FCPA Blog | logo = The FCPA Blog Logo.png | company_type = | foundation = August 2007 | founder = [[Richard L. Cassin]] | location_city = [[Singapore]] | location_country = | area_served = | key_people =[[Richard L. Cassin]], [[Publisher and Editor]]
Andy Spalding, [[Senior Editor]]
Elizabeth Spahn, [[Contributing Editor]]
Jessica Tillipman, [[Contributing Editor]]
Eric Carlson, [[Contributing Editor]]
Philip Fitzgerald, [[Contributing Editor]]
Michael Kuria, [[Contributing Editor]]
Thomas Fox, [[Contributing Editor]]
Marc Alain Bohn, [[Contributing Editor]]
Michael Scher, [[Contributing Editor]]
Bill Waite, [[Contributing Editor]]
Shruti J. Shah, [[Contributing Editor]] | owner = | num_employees = | url = [http://www.fcpablog.com/ The FCPA Blog] | website_type = News & [[blog]]ging | language = English | advertising = | current_status = Active | alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 286,957 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/fcpablog.com |title= Fcpablog.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }} }} '''The FCPA Blog''' is an international website for commentary and news about anti-corruption compliance and enforcement founded by [[Richard L. Cassin]].[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/rupert-murdoch-not-fit-to-run-a-major-company-says-a-british-panel/2012/05/01/gIQApey9tT_story.html The Washington Post][https://www.usatoday.com/money/companies/regulation/story/2012-05-02/foreign-bribes-in-corporate-world/54706232/1 USA Today] The website's primary focus is compliance with and enforcement of the United States [[Foreign Corrupt Practices Act]] (FCPA).[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/business/11tyson.html The New York Times - Tyson Settles U.S. Charges of Bribery] Topics covered by posts have included developments and trends in international anti-corruption enforcement, relevant [[international treaties]] and conventions, correlations between corruption and national and global [[security]], other criminal activity, and economic development and [[poverty]]. Commentary on the FCPA Blog has dealt with the effects of corruption on government institutions, individuals, and society in general, and how government and transnational anti-corruption enforcement policies impact [[international relations]] and global investment practices. ==History== The FCPA Blog was launched by [[Richard L. Cassin]] from [[Singapore]] in August 2007. With a reported 70,000 or more monthly [[pageviews]] from virtually every country, the FCPA Blog is one of the leading anti-corruption compliance websites in the world. It is regularly cited by global, national, and local news organizations as a source for reporting about the FCPA and international anti-corruption enforcement. In 2010, the FCPA Blog published the first version of its list of the Top Ten FCPA Cases,[http://www.fcpablog.com/blog/2011/12/29/with-magyar-in-new-top-ten-its-90-non-us.html With Magyar In New Top Ten, It's 90% Non-U.S.] which is now a regularly updated feature of the FCPA Blog and is referred to in numerous news accounts and legal submissions in court cases related to the FCPA. The FCPA Blog has also been cited in academic research papers[http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1629483 Discovering Secrets: Act of State Defenses to Bribery Cases By Elizabeth Spahn] published in the United States and France. The Risk Management Monitor listed the FCPA Blog as one of the ten best risk-management and insurance-industry blogs.[http://www.riskmanagementmonitor.com/tag/the-fcpa-blog/ The 10 Best Industry Blogs] ==Editors and Authors== The FCPA Blog publishes multiple daily posts. They are written by [[Richard L. Cassin]], who serves as editor-in-chief, and by a team of Contributing Editors and other contributors.[http://www.fcpablog.com/editors/ The FCPA Blog - Editors] Posts have originated from the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada, France, Australia, New Zealand, [[Thailand]], China, and other countries. The FCPA Blog features regular profiles and interviews of global anti-corruption and compliance leaders from the public and private sectors.[http://www.fcpablog.com/blog/tag/profiles The FCPA Blog - Profiles] As of June 2012, nearly 1,700 posts had appeared on the FCPA Blog.[http://www.fcpablog.com/archive/ The FCPA Blog - Archive] The posts typically feature informal (non-technical) writing accessible to both legal and compliance professionals and the general public. Most posts do not exceed 300 words. The FCPA Blog also publishes third-party videos that deal with corruption and compliannce-related topics. ==Related Works== In 2011, a collection of posts from the FCPA Blog written by various contributors was published as a book called Be My Guest: Bylined Posts from the FCPA Blog.[https://www.amazon.com/Be-My-Guest-Bylined-Posts/dp/9810891474/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1338271836&sr=8-1 Be My Guest: Bylined Posts from the FCPA Blog] Collections of posts written by [[Richard L. Cassin]] have been collected in two volumes, Bribery Abroad: Lessons from the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act,[https://www.amazon.com/Bribery-Abroad-Second-Lessons-Practices/dp/9810887507/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1338272089&sr=1-3 Bribery Abroad, Second Edition: Lessons from the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act] published in 2008 and a second edition appearing in 2011, and Bribery Everywhere: Chronicles From The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act,[https://www.amazon.com/Bribery-Everywhere-Chronicles-Foreign-Practices/dp/055705348X/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1338272130&sr=1-1 Bribery Everywhere: Chronicles From The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act] published in 2009.[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/28/business/for-wal-mart-lots-of-bribes-but-little-jail-time-common-sense.html?ref=business?hp The New York Times - Bribes Without Jail Time] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.fcpablog.com/ The FCPA Blog] {{DEFAULTSORT:FCPA Blog}} [[Category:Blogs]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2007]] [[Category:Business ethics organizations]] [[Category:Companies of Singapore]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2018}} {{redirect|Wadia}} {{for|the Islamic banking practice|Wadiah}} {{null|date=May 2011}} {{refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox Family | name = Wadia family | image = | crest = | caption = | ethnicity = | region = [[Mumbai]], India | early_forms = | members = [[Ardaseer Cursetjee]]
[[Bahman Pestonji Wadia|Bahman Pestonji]]
[[Darashaw Nosherwan Wadia|Darashaw Nosherwan]]
[[Lovji Nusserwanjee Wadia|Lovji Nusserwanjee]]
[[Neville Wadia]]
[[Dina Jinnah]]
[[Nusli Wadia]]
[[Ness Wadia]]
[[Jehangir Wadia]] | distinctions = | traditions = [[Zoroastrianism]] | otherfamilies = [[Jinnah family]] | heirlooms = [[Wadia Group]] | estate = | meaning = | footnotes = }} The '''Wadia family''' is a [[Parsi]] family from [[Surat, India]] currently based in [[Mumbai, India]] and the [[United States]].{{cite web|url=http://www.zoroastrian.org.uk/vohuman/Article/The%20Wadias%20of%20India.htm|title=The Wadias of India|date=28 May 2018|publisher=Vohuman, A Zoroastrian Educational Institute}} The family is related to the politically prominent [[Jinnah family]]—[[Neville Wadia]] was married to [[Dina Jinnah]]—the only child of [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] and [[Rattanbai Petit]]. The present head of the house is [[Nusli Wadia]], son of Neville and Dina, who runs the [[Wadia Group]] of companies. The Wadia family has three main branches: textiles, shipping, and jewelry. Descendants from each of these branches have made significant contributions to their fields, to their communities, to India, and to the global economy; they have been industrialists, government leaders, medical doctors, and scholars. ==History== [[Lovji Nusserwanjee Wadia]] advanced the Wadia shipbuilding dynasty in 1736, when he obtained a contract from the [[British East India Company]] for building docks and ships in Bombay (present-day [[Mumbai]]). Although the Wadias would eventually come to be considered a Bombay family, many of them remained in Surat, where one branch of the family established a [[ship breaking]] yard (where ships are dismantled) that remains one of the largest of its kind in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.zoroastrian.org.uk/vohuman/Article/The%20Wadias%20of%20India.htm|title=The Wadias of India|date=28 May 2018|publisher=Vohuman, A Zoroastrian Educational Institute}} The poem whose words would become the lyrics of [[The Star-Spangled Banner]], the [[national anthem]] of the [[United States]], were written in 1812 on board a Wadia-built British [[Royal Navy]] ship, {{HMS|Minden}} by [[Francis Scott Key]].{{cite web|url=https://www.thequint.com/news/india/american-anthem-written-on-made-in-india-ship-hms-minden|title=The US National Anthem Was Written Aboard This Made-In-India Ship|date=5 April 2017|publisher=The Quint}} By the 1840s, the family was one of the leading forces in the Indian shipbuilding industry. At that time they had built over a hundred warships for [[United Kingdom|Britain]], and had trading networks around the world. The prominent women of the Wadia family, including Motlibai Maneckji Wadia, Jerbai Nusserwanji Wadia, and Lady Hirabai Cowasji Jehangir, were known for their philanthropy in providing financial support to [[Zoroastrian]] temples, establishing schools and hospitals, and supporting the arts in the 1800s.{{cite web|url=http://www.zoroastrian.org.uk/vohuman/Article/The%20Wadias%20of%20India.htm|title=The Wadias of India|date=28 May 2018|publisher=Vohuman, A Zoroastrian Educational Institute}} More recently, [[Neville Wadia]] continued the philanthropic tradition of his family by continuing to establish hospitals and schools.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituaryneville-wadia-1308408.html|title=Obituary: Neville Wadia|date=6 August 1996| first=Kuldip | last=Singh | newspaper=The Independent | accessdate=10 August 2018 }} The Wadia family has endowed [[Nowrosjee Wadia College]] in Pune. Lovji Nusserwanjee Wadia's great grandsons, [[JBH Wadia]] and [[Homi Wadia]] founded [[Wadia Movietone]] in 1933, which had its studios at Lovji Castle (Lovejee Castle) in [[Chembur]], [[Mumbai, India]]. The company has a ship as its logo, honoring their family legacy.{{cite web | title = Surat's Wadias created Fearless Nadia | url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/Surats-Wadias-created-Fearless-Nadia/articleshow/6668162.cms?referral=PM# |date=2 Oct 2010| accessdate = 2014-09-18 | publisher = The Times of India }} The family is related to [[Pakistan]]'s politically prominent [[Jinnah family]], through [[Neville Wadia]], who was married to [[Dina Jinnah]] from 1938 to 1943, and had two children together, Diana and [[Nusli Wadia]]. Dina was the daughter of [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] and [[Rattanbai Petit]], the former is the founder of [[Pakistan]], while the later was the daughter of [[Tata family#Prominent members|Sylla Tata]] and [[Petit baronets|Dinshaw Maneckji Petit]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009%5C06%5C30%5Cstory_30-6-2009_pg7_32 |title=Aslam Jinnah's claim of being Quaid's family disputed |date=30 June 2009 |work=[[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]] |first=Amar |last=Guriro |accessdate=11 September 2012 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news|date=2 November 2017|url=https://www.samaa.tv/pakistan/2017/11/dina-wadia-said-last-meeting-jinnah/|title=Dina Wadia’s last meeting with Quaid-e-Azam–in her own words|agency=PTI|work=Samaa|accessdate=2 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/510759/fact-file-jinnahaes-family|title=Fact file: Jinnah's family|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|date=26 December 2009|accessdate=1 November 2017|quote=Dina and Neville lived in Mumbai and had two children, a boy and a girl, before the couple divorced.}} Though Dina took divorce from Neville in 1943, she remained a prominent member of the Wadia family.{{cite news|date=2 November 2017|url=https://www.geo.tv/latest/166321-dina-wadia-and-her-darling-papa|title=Dina Wadia and her darling papa|agency=PTI|work=[[Geo News]]|accessdate=2 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1551486/6-remembering-dina/|title=Remembering Dina|date=17 November 2017|website=Tribune.pk}} ==Notable members== * [[Lovji Nusserwanjee Wadia]] (1702–1774), shipwright, founded [[Wadia Group]] in 1736. * [[Ardaseer Cursetjee]] (1808 – 1877), shipbuilder and engineer. * [[Bahman Pestonji Wadia]] (1881 - 1958), theosophist and labour activist * [[Darashaw Nosherwan Wadia]], (1883 – 1969), geologist, winner of [[Padma Bhushan]] (1958) * [[JBH Wadia]] (1901 - 1986), film director, screenwriter, producer * [[Homi Wadia]] (1911 – 2004), film director, screenwriter, producer * [[Fearless Nadia]] (1908-96), film actress, wife of Homi Wadia * [[Neville Wadia]] (1911 – 1996), chairman Bombay Dyeing (1952–1977) * [[Dina Jinnah]] (1919 – 2017), wife of Neville Wadia, daughter of [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] and [[Rattanbai Petit]] * [[Nusli Wadia]] (b. 1944), son of Neville & Dina Wadia, Chairman of [[Bombay Dyeing]] since 1977 * [[Jim Wadia|Jamshed "Jim" Wadia]] (born 1947), businessman * [[Ness Wadia]], businessman, son of Nusli Wadia * [[Jehangir Wadia]], businessman, son of Nusli Wadia * [[Spenta R. Wadia|Spenta Wadia]], Theoretical Physicist, previous director of ICTS-TIFR. * [[Nina Wadia]] (b. 1968), actress ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.zoroastrian.org.uk/vohuman/Article/The%20Wadias%20of%20India.htm The Wadias of India: Then and Now] *[http://www.humantouchofchemistry.com/ardaseer-cursetjee-wadia.htm Ardaseer Cursetjee Wadia] *[https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/nguyen-nhan-dan-den-thoat-vi-dia-dem-bao-huy/ Nguyen nhan dan den thoat vi dia dem] {{DEFAULTSORT:family, Wadia}} [[Category:Indian shipbuilders]] [[Category:Business families of India]] [[Category:People from Surat]]
